title: State v. Wise
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Stanley Wise Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-001
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January 2, 2008Â Â Â  

APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Chief
  Attorney Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J.
  Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Stanley Wise appeals his convictions for murder, two
  counts of assault and battery with intent to kill (ABWIK), and three counts of
  possession of a firearm while in the commission of a violent crime, as well as
  his sentences of life imprisonment for murder, ten years for each ABWIK charge,
  and five years for each possession of a firearm charge, all to run
  concurrently.Â  Wise contends the trial court erred by admitting certain
  evidence because its presence in the jury room during deliberations unduly
  emphasized the evidence.Â  After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s
  brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State
    v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss[1] Wiseâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
ANDERSON, SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Venture Engineering v. Avery
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Venture
      Engineering, Inc., Respondent
				v.
				Darrell L.
      Avery, Sr., and Jeffrey L. Avery, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-002
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  2, 2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				James C. Rushton, III and Reginald C. Brown, Jr., of Florence, for Appellants.
				Nate Fata, of Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this action to set aside a default judgment, Darrell and Jeffery Avery (the Averys)
  argue the default judgment against them is void due to Venture Engineeringâ€™s,
  Inc. (Venture) failure to properly file the amended complaint.Â  We reverse and
  remand.[1]  
FACTS
In 2002, the Averys, through their company
  Myrtle Beach Developers, LLC, purchased a tract of land in South Carolina.Â  The
  Averys hired Venture to perform engineering and consulting services in
  connection with the property.Â  After Venture provided the services, the Averys
  failed to pay Venture monies due under the contract.Â   
On
  December 4, 2002, Venture brought suit against the Averys, alleging breach of
  contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, fraud, and
  quantum meruit.Â  The Averys, who at this point were represented by counsel,
  timely answered.Â   
In 2004, Venture moved to compel discovery
  and requested leave to file an amended complaint.Â  Attached to the motion for
  leave to file an amended complaint was the amended complaint, which was
  file stamped on July 16, 2004.Â  In addition, the Averysâ€™ counsel moved to be
  relieved.Â   
During
  a hearing, the circuit court considered and granted all three motions.Â  The
  circuit courtâ€™s order gave the Averys thirty days to obtain new counsel, if
  they desired.Â  Otherwise, the order provided Venture should mail all documents
  to the Averysâ€™ address in North Carolina.Â  The circuit court ordered the Averys
  to notify the court, in writing, of any change of address.Â   
On July
  21, 2005, Venture mailed the summons and amended complaint to the Averys.Â  The
  amended complaint was virtually identical to the first except it added a cause
  of action for piercing the corporate veil.Â  However, Venture failed to file the
  amended complaint.Â  The Averys, who were pro se, did not respond
  to the amended complaint.Â   
Due to
  the Averysâ€™ failure to answer the amended complaint, Venture filed an affidavit
  of default.Â  The affidavit erroneously provided the amended complaint was filed
  on July 15, 2005.Â  The circuit court referred the matter to the
  master-in-equity for damages to be assessed, and Venture notified the Averys of
  the reference to the master.Â   
At the damages hearing, which the Averys
  did not attend, Steve PowellÂ  testified on behalf of Venture.Â  Powell testified
  that the Averys owed Venture $79,000 for services rendered.Â  Further, Powell
  testified he aided the Averys in obtaining bids for selling timber and they
  received over $150,000 but failed to pay Venture.Â  Powell stated he felt misled
  because he was unaware that Darrell Avery was in bankruptcy, and both Averys
  had served time in federal prison for the preparation of false and fraudulent
  tax returns.Â  Following Powellâ€™s testimony, Venture argued it was entitled to
  prejudgment interest as well as punitive damages.Â  Venture alleged the Averysâ€™
  dealings with Venture were not out of the ordinary, and the Averys â€œ[took] all
  the dirt, the sand, and the timber [off of the property] and let everyone else
  foreclose on them, and [the Averys] go back to North Carolina [and] file
  bankruptcy.â€Â  Ultimately, the master awarded damages and prejudgment interest
  totaling $104,680.36 and punitive damages in the amount of $395,787.50.Â 
 
The Averys, now represented by counsel,
  moved pursuant to Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP, for a new trial and to have the
  default judgment set aside.Â  At the hearing, the Averys argued, inter alia,
  the judgment against them was void because Venture failed to properly file the
  amended complaint.Â  Venture conceded the amended complaint was not filed but
  argued the motion for leave to amend the complaint had the amended complaint
  attached.Â  The circuit court agreed with Venture that it did not need to refile
  the amended complaint.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court denied the Averysâ€™
  motions.Â  Subsequent to the order of default and judgment, Venture filed the
  amended complaint.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  determination of whether to set aside a default judgment lies within the sound
  discretion of the trial court.Â  Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros. Inc., 298 S.C. 462, 465, 381 S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App.
  1989).Â  The decision of the trial court â€œwill
  not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing of an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Thompson
    v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 902-03 (1989).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial court
  â€œissuing the order was controlled by some error of law or when the order, based
  upon factual, as distinguished from legal conclusions, is without evidentiary
  support.â€Â  In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 259, 495 S.E.2d
  454, 459 (Ct. App. 1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The issue on appeal is whether Ventureâ€™s failure to properly
  file the amended complaint rendered the default judgment against the Averys
  void.Â  For the reasons set forth below, we find the circuit court erred by
  failing to set aside the default judgment.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and
  remand.Â   
Rule 55(a), SCRCP, provides, â€œWhen a party against
  whom a judgment for affirmative relief is sought has failed to plead or
  otherwise defend as provided by these rulesâ€ the clerk of court, after proper
  notification, will enter default.Â Â  It is axiomatic that in order for a party
  to â€œplead or otherwise defendâ€ an action, the action must be properly filed.Â 
  In South Carolina, a civil action is commenced if the summons and
  complaint are filed with the clerk of court and proper service is effectuated.Â  See Rule 3(a), SCRCP (â€œA civil action is commenced when the summons and
  complaint are filed with the clerk of court if [the summons and complaint] are
  [properly served].â€).Â Â  Further, the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure
  require the summons and complaint â€œbe filed before service.â€Â  Rule 5(d),
  SCRCP.Â Â  See McLain v. Ingram, 314 S.C. 359, 360, 444 S.E.2d 512,
  513 (1994) (finding action was not properly commenced when service preceded
  filing).  
In the present
  case, Venture filed the original summons and complaint and then properly served
  the Averys, who timely answered.Â Â  After obtaining permission from the circuit
  court to amend the complaint, Venture served the summons and amended complaint
  before filing.Â  Due to the Averysâ€™ failure to answer the amended complaint,
  Venture sought and obtained a default judgment.Â   
Venture maintains
  the rule requiring filing before service applies to only the original
  pleadings, and the amended complaint falls under the â€œall papersâ€ category
  under Rule 5(d), which provides, â€œ[a]ll papers required to be served upon a
  party . . . shall be filed with the court within five days after service.â€Â 
  Therefore, Venture reasons under Rule 5(d) filing the amended complaint after
  service to the Averys was proper.Â  However, the amended complaint was not filed
  within five days but belatedly filed on May 17, 2006 after the entry of a
  judgment.
Here,
  Venture would have been unable to obtain a default judgment against the Averys
  on the original complaint because the Averys timely answered.Â  The only way the
  Averys could be held in default would be for their failure to answer the
  amended complaint.Â  Therefore, the amended complaint must have been properly
  filed and served in order to trigger the Averysâ€™ duty to answer. See Rule
  5(d).Â  By holding otherwise we would, in essence, allow a litigant to obtain a
  default judgment against a party who failed to answer despite the fact no amended
  action was pending at the court house.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court
  erred by failing to set aside the default judgment.Â Â Â   
The Averys also
  argue the circuit court erred in affirming the masterâ€™s award of prejudgment
  interest.Â  Further, they allege the award of punitive damages violates their
  constitutional rights.Â  Due to the resolution of this case, we decline to
  address the Averysâ€™ remaining arguments.Â  See Â Futch
    v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d
    591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive ).
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the decision of the circuit court is
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
HUFF and PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Combs v. Combs
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				L. Brownell
      Combs, II, Respondent,
				v.
				Wilhelmina
      Combs, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Kershaw County
Â Jeffrey M. Tzerman, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-003
Heard December 12, 2007 â€“ Filed January 2,
  2008 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William S. Tetterton, of Camden, for Appellant.
				Thomas E. Lydon, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  is an appeal from the denial of Appellantâ€™s motion to set aside the judgment of
  foreclosure pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), SCRCP.Â  She maintains the Master-in-Equity in Kershaw County did not have subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.
 
FACTS
In 1983, the parties deeded their ownership in
  property located in Kershaw County, South Carolina, to Diablita, Inc., a
  corporation controlled by Appellant.Â  Prior to being married in 1987, the
  parties signed an antenuptial agreement in which Respondent conveyed any
  ownership he had in Diablita to Appellant, making her the sole owner of the
  corporation.Â  Additionally, the agreement provided all property individually
  owned by either Appellant or Respondent, whether acquired before marriage or
  during the marriage, would remain the property of the individual with title to
  the property.Â   
In
  1992, Diablita gave Ely Place Nominees, LTD., a promissory note and mortgage on
  the Kershaw County property in exchange for a loan of $300,000.Â  Respondent
  testified Ely Place held money on his behalf and made the loan at his
  direction.Â  He indicated the money loaned to Diablita were his personal funds.Â 
 
Appellant
  filed for divorce in 1997 in Florida and did not list the debt Diablita owed to Ely Place.Â  In addition,
  Appellant never raised the issue of the debt during the divorce proceedings.Â 
 
Appellant
  sought to obtain a loan on the property in 1999 and realized the mortgage and
  note to Ely Place were still outstanding.Â  She brought suit in Kershaw County, seeking to have the mortgage and note declared null and void due to fraud.Â 
  The trial court dismissed the case due to the expiration of the applicable
  statute of limitations.Â  Appellant filed an appeal to this court, which
  affirmed the dismissal in Diablita, Inc. v. Ely Place Nominees, Op. No.
  2001-UP-517 (S.C. Ct. App. filed November 27, 2001).
Prior
  to the divorce hearing, Diablita deeded the property to Appellant individually.
  Â The Final Judgment of Dissolution of Marriage was entered in Florida in 2000.Â 
  The divorce decree awarded possession of the Kershaw County property to
  Appellant but did not address the indebtedness in any manner.Â  Additionally,
  the divorce decree affirmed the antenuptial agreement signed by the parties and
  stated that any personal items not specifically addressed by the decree shall
  be the property of the party in possession and control of the item.Â   
In 2002, Ely Place assigned the note and mortgage to Respondent.Â 
  He commenced this action for foreclosure in 2003.Â  Prior to the hearing on the
  action in 2005, Appellant moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter
  jurisdiction.Â  The Master denied the motion.Â  The Master later issued a
  Masterâ€™s Report and Judgment of Foreclosure and Sale without mentioning the
  jurisdictional issue.Â   
Appellant filed an appeal from the denial of her motion to
  dismiss.Â  The appeal was dismissed by this court as interlocutory and not
  immediately appealable.Â  Appellant then filed a motion pursuant to Rule
  60(b)(4), SCRCP, seeking an order setting aside the judgment and sale for lack
  of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The Master denied the motion and this appeal
  followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether to grant or
  deny a motion under Rule 60(b), SCRCP, is within the sound discretion of the
  judge.Â  Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 494, 413 S.E.2d 15, 17 (1992).Â 
  Our standard of review, therefore, is limited to determining whether the Master
  committed an abuse of discretion.Â  BB&T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548,
  551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 502-03 (2006).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the
  judge issuing the order was controlled by an error of law or the order is based
  on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.Â  Tri-County Ice
    & Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782
  (1990).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant maintains
  the Master erred in ruling he had subject matter jurisdiction to hear the
  foreclosure action.Â  She contends the Florida Family Court that heard the
  divorce action retained exclusive jurisdiction over the parties and their
  property.Â  We disagree.
â€œSubject
  matter jurisdiction refers to the courtâ€™s â€˜power to hear and determine cases of
  the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€™â€Â  Watson v.
    Watson, 319 S.C. 92, 93, 460 S.E.2d 394, 395 (1995) (quoting Dove v.
      Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994)).Â  The
  Master-in-Equity is considered a division of the circuit court and obtains
  jurisdiction through an order of reference from the circuit court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-11-15 (Supp. 2006); Rule 53, SCRCP.Â  A master would then
  have subject matter jurisdiction over a properly referred foreclosure action.Â  See Wachovia Bank of South Carolina, N.A. v. Player, 341 S.C. 424, 427, 535
  S.E.2d 128, 129 (2000).
The
  Florida Family Court was endowed with the jurisdiction to decide issues related
  to the marital property of the parties and the equitable division of that
  property.Â  See Fla. Stat. Ann. Â§ 61.075.Â  The Florida Court exercised
  this jurisdiction in approving the antenuptial agreement signed by the parties
  and in specifically allocating to each party the property individually titled
  in his or her name and the personal property he or she controlled.Â   
Assuming
  the Florida court had the power to determine issues related to the note and
  mortgage on the property, neither party raised the issues, and the Florida court did not address the debt in its divorce decree.Â  The sole determination by
  the Florida court would have been to determine to which party the property and
  any interest in Diablita or Ely Place belonged.Â  Cf. Davis v.
    Dieujuste, 496 So.2d 806 (Fla. 1986).Â  The Florida court upheld the
  antenuptial agreement which, when applied in this case, resulted in the Kershaw County property being distributed to Appellant and Respondent retaining whatever
  interest he may have had in Ely Place.Â  There were no further issues related to
  the property for the Florida court to determine.Â  Additionally, the Florida divorce action would not have been an appropriate forum for a foreclosure action to
  occur because Ely Place held the note and mortgage, and it was not a party to
  the divorce action.Â  As a result, the divorce decree did not eliminate the
  third-party debt to Ely Place, and res judicata would not apply
  to prevent a foreclosure in South Carolina.Â  See, e.g., Florida Bar
    v. Rodriguez, 959 So.2d 150, 158 (Fla. 2007) (requiring â€œ(1) identity of
  the thing sued for; (2) identity of the cause of action; (3) identity of
  persons and parties to the action; and (4) â€˜identity of quality in persons for
  or against whom claim is made.â€™â€).Â  Moreover, under Florida law, a suit seeking
  transfer of title to real estate is considered to be quasi in rem and must be
  brought in the county where the land is situated.Â  See Goedmakers v.
    Goedmakers, 520 So.2d 575 (Fla. 1988).Â  Although a mortgage does not
  transfer title, it subjects the title to a lien, and a successful foreclosure
  would transfer legal title to the subject property.Â  Thus, the Florida divorce court did not have jurisdiction to entertain an action to foreclose or
  invalidate the mortgage lien in question.Â  See Hammond v. DSY
    Developers, LLC, 951 So.2d 985, 988-89 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2007); Ocean
      Bank v. State Dept. of Financial Services, 902 So.2d 833, 835 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2005).Â  
 
Even
  though the Florida court retained jurisdiction to enforce the divorce decree,
  this would extend only to those issues arising under the divorce decree.Â  The
  issues would relate to the possession of the property and not the validity of
  the note and mortgage assumed by Appellant with the allocation of the
  property.Â  In addition, the Florida Family Court would not have jurisdiction
  over Ely Place as it was a separate entity from Respondent and not a party in
  the Florida action.Â   
Accordingly,
  the divorce proceedings would not act as a bar to the South Carolina courtâ€™s
  having jurisdiction over the foreclosure action.Â  Because Appellant does not
  dispute the efficacy of the referral to the Master, the Master clearly had
  subject matter jurisdiction to hear the foreclosure action.Â   
CONCLUSION
We
  find the Master had subject matter jurisdiction to hear the foreclosure
  action.Â  Therefore, the order of the Master denying Appellantâ€™s Rule 60(b)(4)
  motion is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF
  AND PIEPER, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

title: Ex Parte: Smith v. Auto-Owners Insurance
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ex Parte: 
				Brandon Smith,
          as Personal Representative of the Estate of Tracy Smith, Deceased, Appellant,
				v.
				Auto-Owners
      Insurance Company, Respondent,
				
				In Re: 
				Lewis Lesesne
          Scott, Plaintiff,
				v.
				 
				Wayne K.
      McGraw, Jr., Defendant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-004
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  2, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Daniel Lawrence Prenner, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Robert Eric Davis, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this
  action to recover under a policy of underinsured motorist coverage, the Estate
  of Tracy Smith (the Estate) argues the statutory definition of â€œinsuredâ€ does
  not restrict an insured to living in one household for purposes of insurance
  coverage.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Ernest
  and Brenda Smith (collectively the Smiths) purchased land in Spartanburg County and established a residence there (the Spartanburg County home) in the
  1970s.Â  Later, the Smiths subdivided some of the acreage and deeded ownership
  of ten acres to each of their four sons.Â  Ernest retained, in his name alone,
  ownership of this home and the land immediately surrounding it.Â  In 1989, while
  still living at the Spartanburg County home, the Smiths purchased a second home
  in Laurens County (the Laurens County home).Â   
The
  Smiths lived at the Spartanburg County home, periodically visiting the Laurens County home as their â€œsummer home.â€Â  When Brenda Smith retired in November of 1999,
  she moved to the Laurens County home.Â  While he visited his wife in Laurens County on occasion, Ernest Smith continued to work full-time and to live at the Spartanburg   County home.Â  Ernest Smith retired in March of 2003 and moved to the Laurens County home with Brenda.Â  However, Ernest Smith continued to work part-time in Spartanburg   County after his retirement.Â  Ernest occasionally stayed in the Spartanburg   County home when working and kept some personal items and clothing there.Â  Ernest
  did not have his driverâ€™s license updated to reflect his Laurens County address.Â  However, Ernest stated he â€œconsidered [his] household after March 2003 to be
  with [his] wifeâ€ at the Laurens County home.Â   
Tracy
  Smith was the Smithsâ€™ 42-year-old son.Â  In May of 2004, Tracy was living in the
  Spartanburg County home.Â  He would occasionally visit his parents at the Laurens County home, but he did not live there.Â  On May 24, 2004, Tracy was a passenger in
  an automobile owned and driven by Wayne K. McGraw, Jr.Â  McGrawâ€™s vehicle
  collided with Lewis Lesesne Scottâ€™s vehicle, and Tracy was killed in the
  accident.Â  Tracy had no automobile insurance at the time of his death.Â   
At
  the time of Tracyâ€™s death, the Smiths owned and paid taxes on the Spartanburg   County home.Â  They did not maintain insurance on that home.Â  The Smiths insured
  their automobiles through the Auto-Owners Insurance Company (Auto-Owners).Â  The
  automobile insurance policy listed the Laurens County home as the Smithsâ€™
  residence.Â   
After
  the wreck, Scott sued McGraw.Â  Tracyâ€™s son, Brandon Smith, intervened on behalf
  of the Estate and subsequently joined Auto-Owners as a defendant.Â  Scott and
  McGraw settled with each other and with the Estate and are not parties to this
  appeal.Â  The Estate and Auto-Owners submitted the issue of â€œwhether Tracy Smith
  qualifies as an insured under Ernest and Brenda Smithâ€™s underinsured motorist
  coverageâ€ to the trial court for determination.Â  In an order dated September
  28, 2006, the circuit court ruled Tracy Smith was not an insured party under
  his parentsâ€™ policy.Â  This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  determination of coverage under an insurance policy is an action at law.Â  Nationwide
    Mut. Ins.Co. v. Prioleau, 359 S.C. 238, 241, 597 S.E.2d 165, 167 (Ct. App.
  2004); see also Kizer v. Kinard, 361 S.C. 68, 71, 602 S.E.2d 783,
  785 (Ct. App. 2004) (determination of whether underinsured motorist coverage
  applies is an action at law).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the
  appellate court standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of
  law.  Pope v. Gordon, 369 S.C. 469, 474, 633 S.E.2d 148, 151 (2006).  We
  will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless those findings are
  â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an erroneous conception or
  application of the law.â€  Gordon v. Colonial Ins.
    Co. of Cal., 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).
The
  determination of resident relative status is a question of fact, and thus, we
  will not disturb the circuit courtâ€™s ruling if the record contains any evidence
  supporting it.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Estate
  argues the circuit court erred in ruling Tracy Smith was not an insured
  resident of Ernestâ€™s household in Spartanburg County.Â  We do not reach the
  merits of this issue because it is not preserved for our review.Â   
An
  issue must be raised and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for
  appeal.Â  Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 620, 533 S.E.2d
  886, 893 (2000); Iâ€™On v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 421, 526
  S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (stating parties should raise all necessary issues and
  arguments to trial court and attempt to obtain a ruling).Â  While the circuit
  court heard and ruled on the broader issue of whether Tracy qualified as an
  insured under the Smithsâ€™ policy, it did not rule on the issue of whether
  Ernest maintained two households.Â  Additionally, the record does not reflect that
  the Estate filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration requesting a
  ruling on this issue.Â  Accordingly, appellate review of this issue would be
  improper.Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
While
  the circuit court ruled Tracy was not an insured under his parentâ€™s automobile
  policy, the issue of whether he qualified as an insured resident of Ernestâ€™s
  household in Spartanburg County is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and PIEPER, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.Â

Â Diane S. Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-005
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  2, 2008Â  Â Â Â Â 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Gary Slezak, pro se, of Ridgeville, for Appellant.
				Deputy General Counsel Barton J. Vincent, of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Gary Slezak, a prisoner
  serving a life sentence at the South Carolina Department of Corrections for two
  murders and an armed robbery, appeals the order of the circuit court that
  dismisses his appeal from a decision of Administrative Law Judge Division.Â  We
  affirm. [1]
On
  May 15, 2000, Slezak filed an inmate grievance with the South Carolina
  Department of Corrections.Â  It read as follows:

	Request
  that my work credits be corrected to reflect that I be given credit for my
  entire sentence of the court on January 18, 1982.Â  I have not be[en] given work
  credits and my parole eligibility date is incorrect.Â  See S.C. Code Â§
  24-21-635 (1981) & State v. Varner, 310 S.C. 264, 265, 423 S.E.2d
  133, 134 (1992); Al-Shabazz v. State, Op. No. 24995 (S.C. Sup. Ct. refilled Feb. 14, 2000) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 21).Â 
	

Where
  the form asked Slezak to describe the action he wanted taken, he responded, â€œGrant
  work credits for entire sentence since court sentenced me until present [and]
  notify parole board of correction.â€Â   
The
  Department denied Slezakâ€™s grievance after review.Â  Its decision gave January
  26, 1981, as his commitment date, found him not entitled to receive earned work
  credits because of his life sentence, and listed July 21, 2000, as his parole
  eligibility date.Â  Slezak appealed, contending â€œthe controlling date for work
  credits is . . . the date I was sentenced.â€Â  The Department once again denied Slezakâ€™s
  grievance on the ground his life sentence precluded him from earning work
  credits.  
The
  Administrative Law Judge Division thereafter affirmed the Departmentâ€™s decision
  and Slezak appealed to the circuit court, contending his initial parole
  eligibility date was later than it should have been had he received earned work
  credits.Â  That court affirmed the order of the Administrative Law Judge
  Division, finding, among other things, the issue raised by Slezak in his appeal
  regarding his not being given earned work credits to be moot â€œ[e]ven if [Slezak]
  was entitled to the work credits.â€Â   
We
  agree with the circuit court.Â   
The
  record shows July 21, 2000, Slezakâ€™s initial parole date as determined by the
  Department, has long since come and gone.Â  Moreover, he was denied parole on
  that date and, apparently, since that time; consequently, the question of
  whether he should have received a parole hearing at an earlier date because of
  earned work credits to which he may have been entitled is of no moment.Â  He proved
  not to be a candidate for parole in any case.Â  For us to decide the question of
  whether the Department wrongfully denied Slezak earned work credits would
  accomplish nothing and would constitute merely an advisory opinion on our part.Â 
  We do not issue advisory opinions.Â  Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 420, 505
  S.E.2d 344, 354 (Ct. App. 1998).  
Slezak
  also appeals the circuit courtâ€™s holding that the Court of General Sessions
  lacked subject matter jurisdiction at the time he entered his guilty plea.Â 
  This issue is manifestly without merit.Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610
  S.E.2d 494 (2005); see Rule 220(2), SCACR (â€œThe Court of Appeals need
  not address a point which is manifestly without meritâ€).  
Finally,
  Slezak appeals the failure of the circuit court to convert his grievance
  petition into a post-conviction application.Â  This issue was neither raised to
  nor ruled upon by the circuit court and may not now be heard.Â  See Wilder
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 333 (1998) (an issue
  cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and
  ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â Â   
AFFIRMED.
Huff
  and Pieper, JJ. and Goolsby, A.J. concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Pellitteri v. Pellitteri Tile
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Carmen
      Pellitteri, Employee, Respondent,
				v.
				Pellitteri
      Tile, Employer, and South Carolina Property and Casualty Guaranty Company,
      Carrier, Defendants,
				Of whom South
      Carolina Property and Casualty Guaranty Company is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-006
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  2, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				F. Reid Warder, Jr. and Jason A. Williams, both of Charleston, for Appellant
				Malcolm M. Crosland, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this workersâ€™ compensation case, South Carolina Property and Casualty Insurance
  Guaranty Association appeals the award of temporary total disability benefits
  and reimbursement for prior medical expenses to Carmen Pellitteri.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
On January 26, 2002, Pellitteri sustained an injury to
  his left leg arising out of his employment as a tile installer for Pellitteri
  Tile. Â As a result of his injury, Pelliteri underwent surgery on March 8, 2002.
  Â During his recovery, Pelliteri was unable to install tile; but he was able to
  evaluate potential jobs and provide estimates. Â Pellitteri injured his right
  leg on April 1, 2002, while providing an estimate. Â Pellitteri sought medical
  benefits and reimbursement for past due medical expenses relating to his right leg
  injury. Â South Carolina
  Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association (Guaranty Association) denied Pelliteriâ€™s
  claim, arguing the claim was barred by an agreement and release entered into
  between Pellitteri, Pellitteri Tile, and Legion Insurance Company on February
  14, 2003. Â 
After a hearing on November 3, 2004, the single
  commissioner issued an order finding Pellitteri sustained a compensable injury
  to his right leg. Â The commissioner further found the release did not bar
  Pellitteriâ€™s claim involving his right leg.[2] Â The commissioner concluded the release â€œcovered only those injuries related to
  the Claimantâ€™s left leg injury which occurred on January 26, 2002.â€ Â Guaranty
  Association appealed to the appellate panel. The appellate panel affirmed the
  single commissionerâ€™s findings. Â Guaranty Association then sought judicial
  review in the circuit court. Â The circuit court affirmed the order of the full
  commission in its entirety. Â Guaranty Association appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Guaranty Association asserts the release barred Pellitteri from receiving benefits under the South Carolina Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act for his right knee injury.Â  We disagree.
The release provides Pellitteri sustained injuries on
  January 26, 2002, and would receive compensation in the amount of $50,000.00.Â  The
  agreement further provides the sum is:

	Â [I]n full and
  final settlement and satisfaction for any and all claims for further
  compensation and medical [sic] due as the result of any injury or injuries,
  reported or unreported, known or unknown, while an employee of the employer,
  including, but not limited to all claims for permanent and temporary, total and
  partial disability, functional and specific loss, disfigurement, change of
  condition, death and funeral benefits, loss of function or impairment of any
  scheduled or non-scheduled members of the body, any claims of psychological or
  emotional injury or impairment, and past or future medical expenses as the
  result of the injury described herein . . . . 

A release is a contract and rules of contract should be
  used to determine what the parties intended.Â  Ecclesiastes Production
    Ministries v. Outparcel Associates, LLC, 374 S.C. 483, 497, 649 S.E.2d 494,
  501 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The construction of a contract is a question of law for
  the court.Â  Auten v. Snipes, 370 S.C. 664, 669-70, 636 S.E.2d 644, 647 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  In construing a contract, the courts function is to interpret the contracts
  lawful meaning, discover the intention of the parties as provided within the contract,
  and give effect to the partiesâ€™ intention.Â  Id.Â  When a contract is
  clear and unequivocal, its meaning must be determined by its content alone.Â  State
    v. Cochran, 358 S.C. 24, 27, 594 S.E.2d 844, 845 (2004).
Here, the meaning of the release is plain.Â  The release
  provides that it is a â€œfull and final settlementâ€ of all claims â€œas the result
  of the injury described herein.â€ Â The only injury described within the release
  relates to Pellitteriâ€™s left leg.Â  Page one of the release describes
  Pellitteriâ€™s injury as having occurred on January 26, 2002. Â In addition, the
  Workersâ€™ Compensation file number listed in the release is 0201583, the file
  number assigned to Pellitteriâ€™s claim for his left leg injury.Â  Furthermore,
  the third page of the release provides that the â€œcombined effect of
  [Pellitteriâ€™s] prior impairment and the injury or injuries described herein was
  such to produce Eighteen percent (18%) permanent functional impairment of
    [Pellitteriâ€™s] left leg. . . .â€ (emphasis added). Â The language of the
  release does not mention an injury to Pellitteriâ€™s right leg, the file number
  assigned to the claim for Pellitteriâ€™s right leg injury, or the date the right
  leg injury took place.Â  The parties clearly could have included language in the
  release barring claims for Pellitteriâ€™s right leg injury had that been their
  intent as the release was dated after Pellitteri injured his right leg. Â 
Guaranty Association argues broad language in the
  release stating the release is final settlement â€œfor any and all claims for
  further compensation and medical [sic] due as the result of any injury or
  injuries, reported or unreported, known or unknown, while an employee of the
  employerâ€ bars Pellitteri from recovery for all injuries prior to the date of
  approval of the release.Â  The release, however, also includes specific language
  limiting its effect to â€œthe injury or injuries described herein.â€ Â Reading the
  release as a whole, it is clearly limited to claims relating to Pellitteriâ€™s
  left leg injury.Â  See Campbell v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 301 S.C.
  448, 452, 392 S.E.2d 477, 480 (Ct. App. 1990) (stating a release must be read
  as a whole); Thomas-McCain, Inc. v. Siter, 268 S.C. 193, 197, 232 S.E.2d
  728, 729 (1977) (â€œWhere the agreement in question is a written contract, the
  partiesâ€™ intention must be gathered from the contents of the entire agreement
  and not from any particular clause thereof.â€). Â Â 
Guaranty
  Association asserts that even if the release is limited to Pellitteriâ€™s left
  leg injury, Pellitteriâ€™s right leg injury is barred because it resulted from
  the left leg injury.Â  The commissioner, however, found Pellitteriâ€™s right leg
  injury resulted from his work as a tile installer that required Pellitteri to
  perform significant bending, stooping, and kneeling. Â Substantial evidence
  supports the commissionerâ€™s finding.Â  By letter of September 18, 2002,
  Pellitteriâ€™s physician opined â€œI do not believe Mr. Pellitteriâ€™s right knee
  meniscus tear is a result of overuse due to his left knee injury but more the
  overuse due to his occupation, which requires a significant amount of bending,
  stooping and kneeling . . . .â€Â  We therefore affirm the commissionerâ€™s
  finding.Â  See Howell v. Pacific
    Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469,
  471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987) (â€œA decision of the Worker's Compensation
  Commission will not be overturned by a reviewing court unless it is clearly
  unsupported by substantial evidence in the record.â€).
CONCLUSION
For
  the reasons stated above, we hold Pellitteri sustained a compensable injury to
  his right leg, and such injury is not barred by the release.  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF AND PIEPER, JJ. and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The commissioner made several additional findings of
  fact.Â  One such finding, regarding Pellitteriâ€™s average weekly wage, was
  appealed by both parties to the appellate panel.Â  The issue, however, is not
  pertinent to this appeal.

title: State v. Oâ€™Donald
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Christopher Lee
      Oâ€™Donald, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Oconee County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-007
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  2, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMcMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, and
  Assistant Solicitor Christina Theos Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher
  Oâ€™Donald appeals from his convictions for burglary first and grand larceny.Â  Oâ€™Donald
  contends the trial judge erred in (1) trying him in absentia without notice of
  his right to be present and without warning that he would be tried in his absence
  should he fail to attend; and (2) finding the assistant solicitorâ€™s comment
  during closing argument about Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s absence was proper.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
An Oconee County grand jury indicted Oâ€™Donald for grand larceny in an amount greater than
  $5,000, distribution of an imitation controlled substance, and first-degree
  burglary.Â  When Oâ€™Donald posted bond on February 4, 2005, he signed an order
  specifying the methods and conditions of his release.Â  The order read as
  follows:  

	That
  the defendant shall appear at . . .Â  the term of court of general sessions
  beginning on March 21, 2005 . . . and remain there throughout that term of
  court.Â  If no disposition is made during that term, the defendant shall appear
  and remain throughout each succeeding term of court until final disposition is
  made of his case, unless otherwise ordered by the court.Â  

Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s initial trial occurred in August of 2005.Â 
  Oâ€™Donald did not attend the trial.Â  The trial resulted in a hung jury.Â 
  Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s trial was rescheduled for the September 19, 2005 term of court.Â 
  Prior to trial, the solicitorâ€™s office delivered a card to Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s residence
  and Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s bonding company. Â The card stated Oâ€™Donald was required to
  appear in court on September 19, 2005.Â  In addition, the card warned Oâ€™Donald
  that failure to appear would result in a bench warrant, and he could be tried
  in his absence.Â   
On September 21, 2005, the State moved to try Oâ€™Donald
  in absentia.Â  In support of its motion, the State introduced copies of the card
  delivered to Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s residence and the order relating to Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s bond.Â  Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s
  counsel objected and moved for a continuance on the grounds that Oâ€™Donald did
  not receive proper notice. Â Specifically, Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s counsel argued:  

	Your
  honor, my position is if [the solicitorâ€™s office] know[s] where to go and give
  him a note, they know where to go arrest him on a bench warrant, which was
  issued last term. They can take him to the jail and then heâ€™ll be here at the
  next term of court when we can try the case with him here. 

The judge denied the motion
  for a continuance and proceeded with the trial.  
Prior to opening arguments, the trial judge talked to
  the jury concerning Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s absence.Â  The trial judge stated as follows:

	I will
  tell you that the Defendant does not have to be here.Â  Our system allows for a
  Defendant to waive his presence during the course of the trial.Â  The Defendant
  is still presumed innocent, even though [he is] not here, and that is a very
  important tenet.Â  And I know itâ€™s sometimes hard for jurors to get their mind
  around, but that Defendant, even though [he is] not here, is still presumed
  innocent, the burden is still on the State to prove [its] case.Â  So you
  shouldnâ€™t hold it against the Defendant or the Defense that the Defendant is
  not present in the courtroom today. 

The trial adjourned and recovened the next morning.Â  After
  the State and the defense had rested, Oâ€™Donald appeared in the courtroom. Â The trial
  judge questioned Oâ€™Donald regarding his right to be present during the trial. Â Oâ€™Donald
  stated he had talked to his lawyer, he understood he had a right to be present,
  and he understood he was facing up to life imprisonment. Â Oâ€™Donald further
  stated he did not want to be present, and he did not want to talk to his lawyer
  about any other options. Â Oâ€™Donald told the trial judge to â€œhave a good oneâ€
  and left the courtroom. Â The trial judge found Oâ€™Donald understood his rights
  and did not want to be present for the trial.  
The trial resumed,
  and the State and the Defense made closing arguments.Â  During the Stateâ€™s
  closing argument, the assistant solicitor stated, â€œThis is [the victimâ€™s] only
  day in court, itâ€™s Chris Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s only day in court.Â  I submit to you, even
  though heâ€™s not here, for whatever reason, the Judge will tell you you canâ€™t
  consider that.â€ Â Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s counsel objected to the solicitorâ€™s comment because
  it referred to Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s absence. Â The trial judge overruled the objection,
  stating the comment was proper.  
Following closing arguments, the trial judge charged
  the jury.Â  He instructed the jury not to consider the fact that the Defendant
  was not present and did not testify.Â  The trial judge added the Defendant had a
  constitutional right to be absent and silent. Â The trial judge reiterated â€œyou
  are to draw no conclusion whatsoever from the fact that the Defendant in this
  case did not appear or testify[,] . . . [it] should not even be discussed in
  the jury room.Â   
The jury returned
  verdicts of guilty for burglary first and grand larceny in an amount between
  $1,000 and $5,000.Â  The jury found Oâ€™Donald not guilty of distribution of an
  imitation controlled substance.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Trial in Absentia
Oâ€™Donald first asserts the trial judge erred in trying
  him in absentia without making the proper findings of fact that he received
  notice of his right to be present and was warned he would be tried in his
  absence should he fail to attend.Â  We disagree.Â   
Although the Sixth
  Amendment of the Constitution guarantees the right of a criminal defendant to
  be present at trial, this right may be waived.Â  Ellis v. State, 267 S.C.
  257, 260, 227 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1976); State v. Fairey, 374 S.C. 92, 99, 646
  S.E.2d 445, 448 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  Rule 16, SCRCrimP provides:

	Except
  in cases wherein capital punishment is a permissible sentence, a person
  indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies may voluntarily waive his right to be
  present and may be tried in his absence upon a finding by the court that such
  person has received notice of his right to be present and that a warning was
  given that the trial would proceed in his absence upon a failure to attend the
  court.

â€œWhile Rule 16 permits a
  knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to be present, such a waiver is
  permitted only in limited circumstances.â€Â  City of Aiken v. Koontz, 368
  S.C. 542, 547, 629 S.E.2d 686, 689 (2006).Â  The trial court must determine the
  defendant voluntarily waived his right to be present.Â  Id.Â  In addition,
  the trial court must make factual findings that the defendant (1) received
  notice of his right to be present; and (2) was warned that the trial would
  proceed in his absence upon his failure to attend.Â  Id.Â   
Notice
  of the term of court in which the defendant will be tried is sufficient to
  enable the defendant to make an effective waiver of his right to be present.Â  Ellis,
  267 S.C. at 261, 227 S.E.2d at 306.Â  But if the record does not reveal evidence
  that the defendant was given notice of his trial, the resulting conviction in
  absentia cannot stand.Â  State v. Jackson, 290 S.C. 435, 436, 351 S.E. 2d
  167, 167 (1986).
Here,
  it is manifest Oâ€™Donald had notice of the trial because he appeared in the
  courtroom during his trial and testified he did not wish to be present. Â Furthermore,
  the record is replete with evidence that Oâ€™Donald was notified to be in court
  for his trial.Â  The bond order that Oâ€™Donald signed required Oâ€™Donald to be in
  court during the March 21, 2005 term of court and to â€œappear and remain
    throughout each succeeding term of court until final disposition is made of his
    case.â€ (emphasis added).Â  The language requiring Oâ€™Donald to â€œremain
  throughout each succeeding term of courtâ€ is sufficient to put Oâ€™Donald on
  notice of his trial.Â  See City of Aiken 368 S.C. at 548, 629
  S.E.2d at 689 (holding a defendant had notice of his October 20, 2004 trial
  date where the trial date was set by court order and where defendant signed a
  bond form requiring the defendant to appear for trial on June 28, 2004 and
  â€œsuch other times and places as ordered by the courtâ€).Â  In addition, the
  solicitorâ€™s office delivered a card to Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s residence and bonding company
  notifying Oâ€™Donald of the trial date.Â   
Also,
  the trial court made the requisite factual finding relating to whether Oâ€™Donald
  was warned he would be tried in absentia should he fail to attend his trial.Â 
  After questioning Oâ€™Donald concerning this right to be present, the trial court
  found Oâ€™Donald was aware of his right to be present and did not wish to attend
  his trial. Â There is evidence to support this finding. The trial transcript
  shows Oâ€™Donald appeared in the courtroom during his trial and informed the
  trial judge he did not wish to be present.Â  In addition, the bond order
  contained an â€œAcknowledgement by Defendantâ€ paragraph, that read: â€œI understand
  and have been informed that I have a right and obligation to be present at
  trial and should I fail to attend the court, the trial will proceed in my absence.â€
  Â See Fairey, 374 S.C. at 101, 646 S.E.2d at 449 (â€œA bond form
  that provides notice that a defendant can be tried in absentia may serve as the
  requisite notice.â€).
At
  any rate, Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s appearance in the courtroom during the trial and his
  testimony that he did not wish to attend his trial cured any error the trial
  court may have committed regarding Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s right to notice and right to be
  present at his trial and such conduct constituted a waiver of that right.Â 
 
II.Â  Solicitorâ€™s Comments
Oâ€™Donald
  also asserts the trial court erred in overruling his counselâ€™s objection when
  the assistant solicitor made a comment to the jury regarding Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s
  absence.Â   
The
  State may not comment on a defendantâ€™s exercise of a constitutional right.Â  Edmond v. State, 341 S.C. 340, 345, 534 S.E.2d 682, 685 (2000).Â 
  Specifically, the State may not comment either directly or indirectly, on a
  defendantâ€™s silence, failure to testify, or failure to present a defense.Â  McFadden
    v. State, 342 S.C. 637, 640, 539 S.E.2d 391, 393 (2000).Â  Improper comments
  on a defendantâ€™s exercise of a constitutional right, however, do not
  automatically require reversal if they are not prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State
    v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 554, 514 S.E.2d 584, 591 (1999).
Here, during the
  Stateâ€™s closing argument, the assistant solicitor made an indirect comment regarding Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s absence.Â  The assistant solicitor stated, â€œitâ€™s Chris Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s
  only day in court[,] . . .Â  even though heâ€™s not here, for whatever reason, the
  Judge will tell you you canâ€™t consider that.â€ Â The trial judge, however, thoroughly
  charged the jury concerning Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s absence.Â  In his opening charge, the
  trial judge told the jury a Defendant may waive his presence during trial, and despite
  the Defendantâ€™s absence, he is still presumed innocent and the burden is still
  on the State to prove its case. Â The judge added that the jury was not to hold Oâ€™Donaldâ€™s
  absence against Oâ€™Donald or the defense. Â As part of his closing charges, the
  trial judge told the jury the Defendantâ€™s absence, failure to testify, and
  failure to present a defense were not to be considered. Â In addition, the trial
  judge explained that Oâ€™Donald had a constitutional right to be absent and
  silent.  
We hold the trial
  judgeâ€™s instructions to the jury cured any prejudice to Oâ€™Donald.Â  See Cooper,
  334 S.C. at 554, 514 S.E.2d at 591 Â (holding even if the solicitorâ€™s comments
  referred to Defendantâ€™s failure to testify or present a defense at trial, any
  prejudice was cured by the trial judgeâ€™s instructions); Johnson v. State,
  325 S.C. 182, 480 S.E.2d 733 (1997) (holding even if the comment was improper,
  the trial courtâ€™s instruction that the jury could not consider the defendantâ€™s
  failure to testify in any way and could not hold it against him was sufficient
  to cure any error).
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s rulings are
AFFIRMED.
HUFF AND PIEPER, JJ. and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  William Middleton appeals from the family courtâ€™s order denying his request to
  reduce his child support and alimony obligations, finding him in willful
  contempt for failing to make court-ordered child support and alimony payments,
  and requiring him to pay Julie Middletonâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We affirm pursuant
  to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 305, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000) (noting the
  question of child support is largely within the discretion of the trial judge
  whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is
  shown); Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 138, 336 S.E.2d 884, 888-89
  (Ct. App. 1985) (â€œThe mere fact that a supporting spouseâ€™s salary or income has
  been reduced does not of itself require a reduction of either alimony or child
  support.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2006) (â€œAn adult who willfully
  violates, neglects, or refuses to obey or perform a lawful order of the court .
  . . may be proceeded against for contempt of court.â€); Brandt v. Gooding, 368 S.C. 618, 627, 630
  S.E.2d 259, 263 (2006) (stating that a decision regarding contempt should be
  reversed on appeal only if no evidence supports it or the trial court has
  abused its discretion); Browning v.
    Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 263, 621
  S.E.2d 389, 393 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based
  upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€); Donahue v. Donahue,
  299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989) (â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial
  court.â€); Singleton v. Collins, 251 S.C. 208, 210-11, 161 S.E.2d
  246, 247 (1968) (â€œAn attorney has a right to be paid for professional services
  rendered, and where there is no express contract, the law will imply
  one. . . . Whether the services were rendered, and their value, are matters
  of fact to be decided . . . by the court below, and no appeal lies therefrom if
  the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€).
For
  the foregoing reasons, the family courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

      Rutledge, Appellant.

No. 2008-UP-010
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January

REVERSED and REMANDED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Assistant Chief Legal Counsel John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  This is an appeal from a probation revocation.Â  We reverse and remand for a new probation revocation hearing. [1]
Harold Rutledge
  contends the hearing court erred in finding that he waived his right to
  counsel.Â  Rutledge properly raises this issue for the first time on appeal.Â  See State v. Rocheville, 310 S.C. 20, 25 n.4, 425 S.E.2d 32, 35 n.4 (1993)
  (stating an exception to the contemporaneous objection rule exists when the
  record lacks evidence of a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to
  counsel because a pro se defendant should not be expected to
  raise the issue without assistance of counsel); State v. White, 305 S.C.
  455, 456, 409 S.E.2d 397, 397 (1991) (holding because the defendant appeared pro se at his sentencing hearing, the first time the defendant could raise
  the issue of lack of knowing and intelligent waiver of right to counsel was on
  appeal).
The
  record before us falls far short of establishing that Rutledge waived his right
  to counsel knowingly and intelligently and with the required warning regarding
  dangers of self-representation.Â  See Huckaby v. State, 305 S.C.
  331, 335, 408 S.E.2d 242, 244 (1991) (stating a defendant in a probation
  revocation hearing must be advised of his right to counsel, the hearing court
  must determine if a defendantâ€™s request to proceed pro se constituted a knowing and intelligent waiver, and the hearing court must make
  defendant aware of the dangers of self-representation).Â  Further, the State
  concedes Rutledge was not warned against the dangers of self-representation and
  Rutledge did not affirmatively waive his right to counsel.
We
  reverse the circuit courtâ€™s determination that Rutledge waived his right to
  counsel and remand the case for a new probation revocation hearing.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral
  argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

AND

	
		
			
				2005-CP-46-1093
				
				Ex Parte:
      Donald Lewis Hofer a/k/a Donald L. Hofer a/k/a D.L. Hofer, Appellant,

v.

	
		
			
				Falcon
      Unlimited, LP, Atlantic National Trust, LLC, Aurora Loan Services, Inc.,

Special Referee F. Craig Wilkerson
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-018
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January
  10, 2008Â Â Â  
DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Mark Weston Hardee, of Columbia, for Appellants.
				Weston Adams, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIUM: In this consolidated appeal
  of fourteen foreclosure actions, Donald Lewis Hofer (Hofer) and Falcon
  Unlimited, L.P. (Falcon) argue the special referee erred in dismissing Hofer from
  the proceedings.Â  We dismiss. [1]
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Hofer executed a note and mortgage to Wachovia Bank,
  NA (Wachovia), as successor in interest to First Federal Savings Bank. Â The
  note and mortgage secured various properties in York County, South Carolina.Â 
  Hofer subsequently conveyed the properties to Falcon, the current owner of the
  properties. Â In 1998, Wachovia initiated foreclosure proceedings against Hofer
  and Falcon (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€). Â Wachovia entered into a settlement
  agreement with Appellants in 2001.  
On April
  25, 2005, Wachovia brought the instant foreclosure actions. Â Appellants answered,
  counterclaimed, and requested a jury trial.Â  Wachovia moved to dismiss Hofer
  from the case on the ground that he was not a required or necessary party.Â  By
  order dated January 25, 2006, the special referee dismissed Hofer from the
  proceedings. Â Â Appellants appeal.
LAW / ANALYSIS
The sole
  issue set forth in Appellantsâ€™ brief states as follows:

	The
  special refereeâ€™s orders [sic] dismissing Donald Lewis Hofer from these series
  of foreclosure cases were in error since Donald Lewis Hofer had submitted
  answers with counterclaims and he had asserted his right to a jury trial.

The argument section of Appellantsâ€™
  brief, however, nowhere addresses Hoferâ€™s dismissal from the foreclosure
  proceedings.Â  We therefore decline to address this issue.Â  See First
    Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (stating
  an appellant must provide authority and supporting arguments for his issue to
  be considered on appeal); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi,  358 S.C. 78,
  99, 594 S.E.2d 485, 496 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding an issue is deemed
  abandoned where argued in only a short conclusory statement); Fields v.
    Fields, 342 S.C. 182, 191 n.8, 536 S.E.2d 684, 689 n.8 (Ct. App. 2000)
  (deeming an issue abandoned where the appellant included the issue in the
  statement of issues on appeal but failed to argue the issue in the body of the
  brief).[2]
Appellants argue in
  their brief the special referee erred in dismissing Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims.Â 
  This issue, however, is not set forth in the statement of issues on appeal; therefore,
  this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Rule 208(b)(1)(B),
  SCACR; Langehans v. Smith, 347 S.C. 348, 352, 554 S.E.2d 681, 683 (Ct.
  App. 2001) (stating the appellantâ€™s brief must set forth an issue in the statement
  of issues on appeal to preserve the issue on appeal).Â  Â 
DISMISSED.
HUFF AND PIEPER, JJ. and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  


[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] We note Hoferâ€™s dismissal was without prejudice.Â  The
  order states â€œDismissal of Hofer from the case neither impedes foreclosure nor
  prejudices his ability to proceed in a separate action against the plaintiff
  for alleged personal claims.â€

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Lucille Taylor, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Ave Marie
      Williams, Mattie Ann Wright and Isaac Wright, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marion County
Michael G. Nettles, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-020
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January 10, 2008Â Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Jerry L. Finney, of Columbia, and Ernest A Finney, Jr., of Sumter, for Appellant.
				C. Pierce Campbell, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Lucille Taylor (Lucille) appeals
  an order of the trial court holding Pauline T. Williams (Pauline Williams) and
  Gracie T. Thurmond (Thurmond) were each deeded one acre of land in fee simple
  absolute and not fee simple condition subsequent.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On
  December 14, 1965, D. T. Taylor (D. T.), Lucilleâ€™s father, executed a Last Will
  and Testament and a first codicil.Â  Lucille was devised a tract of land,
  subject to a life estate in favor of D. T.â€™s wife, Edith Taylor.Â  D. T.
  fathered Pauline Williams and Thurmond.Â  Ave Marie Williams (A. M. Williams)
  and Mattie Ann Wright are Pauline Williamsâ€™ daughters.Â  Mattie Ann Wright is
  married to Isaac Wright (collectively the Wrights).
D. T.â€™s
  codicil provided in relevant part:

	I hereby
  amend ITEM I of the said will so as to provide that in the event my daughter,
  Gracie Thurmond, or my daughter, Pauline Williams, or both of them, desire to
  obtain an acre of land each as a home site for themselves that my wife Edith
  Taylor and my daughter Lucile [sic] Taylor convey to them, or either of them, a
  deed for such one acre of land for each of them upon the payment of the sum of
  One ($1.00) Dollar by each of them for the said land.Â  

D. T. passed away on February
  3, 1966, and his Last Will and Testament and the codicil were duly probated.
On
  March 19, 1974, Lucille and Edith Taylor conveyed Pauline Williams and Thurmond
  each one acre of the land D. T. devised them.Â  The granting clause in Pauline
  Williamsâ€™ deed reads: Â â€œEdith Taylor and Lucile [sic] Taylor . . . have
  granted, bargained, sold and released, by these presents do grant, bargain,
  sell and release unto the said Pauline T. Williams, her heirs and assigns, forever.â€Â 
  In Thurmondâ€™s deed, the granting clause contains identical language:Â  â€œEdith
  Taylor and Lucile [sic] Taylor . . . have granted, bargained, sold and released,
  by these presents do grant, bargain sell and release unto the said Gracie T.
  Thurmond, her heirs and assigns, forever.â€
Following
  a description of the conveyed property, each deed contains a â€œpurpose clauseâ€
  noting:

	This
  deed is being executed by the grantors herein in compliance with the terms and
  conditions of the first Codicil, dated December 14, 1965, to the Last Will and
  Testament of D. T. Taylor, dated December 14, 1965, which is duly filed in the
  office of the Judge of Probate for Marion County in Probate Roll No. 6670, and
  the property herein conveyed is for the use by the grantees as â€œa home siteâ€ as
  more fully set forth in the aforedescribed Codicil.

Both
  deeds have habendum clauses located after the purpose clause which say:Â  â€œTo
  Have and to Hold all and singular the premises before mentioned unto the said
  Pauline T. Williams [Gracie T. Thurmond], her Heirs and Assigns forever.â€Â 
 
Thurmond
  subsequently deeded her parcel to Pauline Williams.Â  On January 21, 1991, Pauline
  Williams conveyed one tract of her land to A. M. Williams and the other to the
  Wrights.Â  Neither Thurmond nor Pauline Williams used their respective tracts of
  land as home sites.
On
  August 31, 2005, Lucille commenced suit to quiet title to the two tracts of
  land conveyed to Pauline Williams and Thurmond, now owned by the Wrights and A.
  M. Williams.Â  Lucille sought to have the trial court declare her the fee simple
  owner of both parcels.Â  The court denied her claim, explaining:

	When
  [Lucille Taylor] and Edith Taylor conveyed fee simple absolute estate in the
  granting clause by use of clear and plain words of inheritance, the provisions
  inserted in the deeds after the descriptions of the property to the effect that
  the property had to be used as a home site by Gracie T. Thurmond and Pauline T.
  Williams were not conditions subsequent, and the deeds to Gracie T. Thurmond
  and Pauline T. Williams conveyed fee simple absolute estates.

ISSUE

	1.     Did the trial court err in finding
  both deeds conveyed fee simple absolute?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[T]he
  construction of a clear and unambiguous deed is a question of law for the
  court.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 303 (2001); Gardner v.
    Mozingo, 293 S.C. 23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 392 (1987); Hammond v.
      Lindsay, 277 S.C. 182, 184, 284 S.E.2d 581, 582 (1981).Â  â€œ[I]t is the duty
  of the court to construe deeds and determine their legal effect, where there is
  no such ambiguity as requires parol proof and submission to the jury.â€Â Â  26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 168 (2001); Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C.
  578, 590, 635 S.E.2d 649, 655 (Ct. App. 2006).

	Deeds
  are construed to determine the intent of the parties.Â  To construe a deed, a
  court looks first at the language of the instrument because the court presumes
  it declares the intent of the parties.Â  When, and only when, the meaning of the
  deed is not clear, or is ambiguous or uncertain, will a court resort to
  established rules of construction to aid in the ascertainment of the grantorâ€™s
  intention by artificial means where such intention cannot otherwise be
  ascertained.

23 Am.Jur.2d Deeds Â§
  192 (2002).Â  â€œ[I]f the language of the deed is unambiguous, then its
  interpretation is a question of law to be resolved by the reviewing court without
  resort to extrinsic evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œWhile a trial courtâ€™s findings of
  fact in a nonjury action at law should not be disturbed on appeal unless they
  are without evidentiary support, a reviewing court is free to decide questions
  of law with no particular deference to the trial court.â€Â  Hunt v. Forestry
    Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 569, 595 S.E.2d 846, 848-849 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  See Okatie River, L.L.C., v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327,
  334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 479 (2003) (â€œIn an action at law, tried without a jury,
  the appellate court standard of review extends only to the correction of errors
  of law.â€); Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320,
  327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000); Rickborn v. Liberty Life Ins. Co., 321
  S.C. 291, 296, 468 S.E.2d 292, 295 (1996); State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v.
    Moorer, 330 S.C. 46, 51, 496 S.E.2d 875, 878 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œIn legal
  actions, our scope of review extends only to the correction of errors of
  law.â€).
DISCUSSION
Lucille
  asserts the trial court erred in finding the deeds to Pauline Williams and
  Thurmond conveyed the properties in fee simple absolute.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[A]
  complete and absolute estate created in the granting clause cannot be cut down
  by subsequent provisions in the deed.â€Â  Abbeville County v. Knox, 267
  S.C. 38, 40, 225 S.E.2d 863, 864 (1976) (citing Stylecraft, Inc. v. Thomas,
  250 S.C. 495, 498, 159 S.E.2d 46, 47 (1968)).Â  â€œWhile
  it is a cardinal rule of deed construction that the intention of the grantor
  must be ascertained and effectuated, this intention cannot stand
  if it contravenes some well settled rule of law or public policy.â€Â  Hunt
    v. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 571-572, 595 S.E.2d 846, 850 (Ct. App.
  2004); Wayburn v. Smith, 270 S.C. 38, 41, 239 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1977).Â  The South Carolina Court of Appeals â€œwill not
  undertake to overthrow a rule of property so long established.â€ Purvis v. McElveen, 234 S.C. 94, 102, 106 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1959); Hunt, 358 S.C. at 571-572, 595 S.E.2d at 850.Â  â€œThis rule of
  construction must be adhered to even if it runs contrary to the express
  intentions of the grantor.â€Â  Hunt, 358 S.C. at 572, 595 S.E.2d at 850; Stylecraft, 250 S.C. at 497, 159 S.E.2d at 47. 
 
Our
  Supreme Court best expressed this contention in Creswell v. Bank of Greenwood, 210 S.C. 47, 55, 41 S.E.2d 393, 397 (1947) (quoted in Hunt, 358 S.C. at 572, 595 S.E.2d at 850):

	[I]ntention is unavailing to avoid [a rule
  of law] where words of settled legal import are used and contrary principles
  are encountered. In such cases the intention will be conclusively presumed to
  accord with the established meaning of the words and to conform to the fixed
  rules of construction. Otherwise there would be little stability of land
  titles.

Applying Creswell, this Court in Hunt declared, â€œUpon
  finding that the granting clause of the 1937 deed constitutes a definite grant
  in fee simple, this court must hold that the purpose clause following the
  property description is ineffectual.â€Â  358 S.C. at 572, 595 S.E.2d at 850.
In
  this case, the granting clauses each convey a fee simple absolute.Â  The purpose
  clauses attempting to restrict the property grants to fee simple condition
  subsequent are ineffectual.Â  While Lucille contends it was the intent of the
  grantors to convey a fee simple condition subsequent to both Pauline Williams
  and Thurmond, this Court will not ignore the clear and unambiguous language in
  the deeds.Â  Therefore, we find both granting clauses in the deeds to Pauline
  Williams and Thurmond constitute definite grants of fee simple absolute and the
  purpose clauses are of no consequence.
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
