THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Joseph A.
      Dozier, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-047
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January
  14, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
				Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, Third Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Joseph A. Dozier (Dozier)
  appeals his conviction for armed robbery, arguing the trial court erred by (1)
  refusing to charge the jury on strong armed robbery or common law robbery and
  (2) deleting the element of â€œreasonably believedâ€ from the jury re-charge.Â  We
  affirm.  
FACTS
On
  February 28, 2005, Dozier entered a convenience store in Clarendon County under the guise of purchasing candy.Â  As the cashier counted his change, Dozier
  displayed a handgun.Â  Dozier then reached into the cash register and took
  approximately $120.Â  Surveillance cameras at the convenience store recorded the
  incident.  
Shortly
  after an investigating officer reviewed the surveillance tape, a vehicle
  matching the one on the tape was found abandoned in a nearby secluded area.Â  The cashier identified the abandoned vehicle as the vehicle used during the
  commission of the robbery.Â   
Law
  enforcement then canvassed the nearby area for a suspect.Â  After review of the
  surveillance tape, law enforcement identified Dozier as a man they questioned earlier
  at a nearby hotel.Â  However, upon return to the hotel, Dozier was no longer at
  the hotel.  
Law
  enforcement learned Gloria Sweat (Sweat) leased the vehicle used in the
  robbery.Â  Law enforcement contacted Sweat, and she identified Dozier in a
  picture.Â  Sweat explained Dozier was at her house the night before the robbery.Â 
  Sweat added that when she awoke both her car keys and car were missing.Â  Law
  enforcement subsequently arrested Dozier, and he then admitted to robbing the
  convenience store.Â Â   
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  At trial, the cashier identified
  Dozier as the person who robbed the convenience store and testified Dozier appeared to use a real gun during the
  robbery.Â  At the close of evidence, the trial court
  denied Dozierâ€™s request to charge the jury on the lesser included offense of
  strong armed or common law robbery.Â  The trial court instructed the jury on
  armed robbery and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent
  crime.Â  After the jury began its deliberation, the foreman returned asking for
  further instructions on armed robbery.Â  The trial court re-charged the jury on
  the elements of armed robbery.Â  The jury found Dozier guilty of armed robbery
  and possession of a weapon during a violent crime.Â  Dozier received a
  mandatory life sentence.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review
  errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court
  unless clearly erroneous.  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545
  S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).  â€œThe appellate court does not re-evaluate the
  facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but simply determines
  whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€ Â State v.
    Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 583, 575 S.E.2d 852, 855 (Ct. App. 2003). Â If any
  evidence exists in the record, this Court should affirm the trial court.  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Jury Charge
Dozier
  argues the trial court erred by refusing to charge the jury on strong armed
  robbery or common law robbery.Â  We disagree.Â   
Generally, the
  trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462,
  472-73 (2004).Â  â€œThe law to be charged to the
  jury is determined by the evidence presented at trial.â€Â  State v. Brown,
  362 S.C. 258, 262-63, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  If any evidence
  supports a jury charge, the trial court should grant the request.Â  Id. at 263, 607 S.E.2d at 95.Â  To warrant reversal, a trial courtâ€™s refusal to give
  a requested jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the
  defendant.Â  Id.Â  â€œ[J]ury instructions should be considered as a whole,
  and if as a whole they are free from error, any isolated portions which may be
  misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  State v. Aleksey, 343
  S.C. 20, 27, 538 S.E.2d 248, 251 (2000).Â   
â€œUpon
  indictment for a greater offense, a trial court has subject matter jurisdiction
  to convict a defendant for any lesser included offense.â€ State v. Tyndall,
  336 S.C. 8, 21, 518 S.E.2d 278, 285 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  A lesser included offense
  instruction is only required when the evidence warrants such an instruction.Â  Id.Â Â Â  It is not error to refuse to charge the lesser included offense unless evidence
  exists which tends to show the defendant was guilty only of the lesser included
  offense.Â  Id.Â  The trial court should refuse to charge a lesser included
  offense where there is no evidence to show the defendant committed the lesser
  rather than the greater offense.Â  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 170, 478
  S.E.2d 260, 268 (1996).Â  If based upon the evidence, a jury could rationally
  find the defendant guilty of the lesser offense, due process requires a lesser
  included offense be charged.Â  Tyndall, 336 S.C. at 21-22, 518 S.E.2d at
  285.
 â€œStrong armed
  robbery is defined as the felonious or unlawful taking of money, goods, or
  other personal property of any value from the person of another or in his
  presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.â€Â  State v. Rosemond,
  356 S.C. 426, 430, 589 S.E.2d 757, 758 (2003).Â  Armed robbery, on the other
  hand, is proved by establishing â€œthe
  commission of a robbery and either one of the two additional elements: (1) that
  the robber was armed with a deadly weapon or (2)
  that the robber alleged that he or she was armed with a deadly weapon, either by action or words, while using a representation of a deadly
  weapon or any object which a person present during the commission of the
  robbery reasonably believed to be a deadly weapon.â€Â  State v. Jones, 342
  S.C. 248, 252-53, 536 S.E.2d 396, 398 (Ct. App. 2000) (quotations omitted).
In
  view of the evidence presented in this case, the trial court did not err in
  denying Dozierâ€™s request to charge the lesser included offense of strong armed
  or common law robbery.Â  The evidence shows Dozier entered into a convenience
  store and removed money from the cash register while brandishing a gun.Â  Further,
  the cashier testified he thought the gun was real.Â  Therefore no evidence tends
  to show Dozier was guilty only of strong armed robbery.Â  The only reasonable
  inference to be drawn from the totality of the evidence is Dozier committed the
  offense while in possession of a deadly weapon, or at the very least, Dozier
  alleged he was armed with a deadly weapon during the commission of the robbery,
  and the cashier reasonably believed it to be a deadly weapon.Â   
Accordingly,
  we find the trial court did not err by refusing to charge the jury on strong
  armed or common law robbery.Â   
II.Â Â Jury Re-charge
Dozier next argues the trial court erred by deleting
  the element of â€œreasonably believedâ€ from the re-charge to the jury of the instruction
  for armed robbery.Â  We disagree.
â€œA jury charge is
  correct if, when the charge is read as a whole, it contains the correct
  definition and adequately covers the law.Â  In re McCracken, 346 S.C 87,
  94, 551 S.E.2d 235, 239 (2001).Â  
Dozier
  maintains the trial court erroneously deleted the words â€œreasonably believedâ€
  from the re-charge of the law.Â  The record demonstrates the trial court used
  the words â€œreasonably believedâ€ at least three times during the re-charge of
  the law.Â  In addition, the trial court cited relevant portions of South Carolina case law to aid the jury in understanding the elements of armed robbery.Â  Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s re-charge of the law, when read as whole, contained the
  correct instruction on the elements of armed robbery.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the trial
  court is
AFFIRMED.[1]
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  In

  Browns contend the family court erred in finding they were not entitled to an
  equitable interest in Husband and Wifeâ€™s house (the House).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in Ohio on November 27, 1982, and they moved to Greenville, South Carolina in 1985.Â  In
  1989, Husband entered into a lease contract with an option to purchase the
  House and 12.9 acres of property in Travelers Rest, South Carolina.Â  That
  same year, the Browns moved from Florida to Greenville County.Â  Following their
  purchase of the House, Husband and Wife continued to reside in a house they
  were renting.Â  In 1992, the Browns moved into the House and from that
  time, they lived there six months out of
  the year without paying any rent.Â  Many people, including the Browns,
  contributed to renovating the House.Â  In 1995, Husband and Wife built a new home on the property
  where they resided through the remainder of the marriage.Â   
Husband filed for divorce on November 14,
  2000 on the grounds of adultery. Â On January 9, 2001, Wife filed an answer and
  counterclaim, seeking affirmative relief.Â  This action was administratively
  dismissed, and a new action was commenced to litigate the remaining issues
  between the parties.Â  Wife filed an answer on June 18, 2002, which incorporated
  her previous answer and counterclaim.Â  Thereafter, on June 22, 2002, she filed
  an amended answer and third-party complaint, in which Wife alleged the Browns
  were necessary parties to the divorce action because Husband and the Browns had
  â€œcommon financial interests,â€ and Wife believed they might claim an interest in
  the House and property surrounding the marital residence.Â  Pursuant to a
  consent order filed on February 21, 2003, Wifeâ€™s action against the
  Browns was consolidated with the divorce action.Â  
On May 12, 2003, Wife filed a motion to
  compel discovery against the Browns, which the family court granted.Â  On
  October 6, 2003, the family court issued a consent order requiring the Browns
  to pay Wife $1,235 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs based on the prior motion to
  compel.Â   
At the final hearing on February 7 and 8,
  2006, the family court found the Browns had no interest in the House.Â  Further,
  the family court ordered the Browns to pay $5,006.60 of Wifeâ€™s expert witness
  fee and $5,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The Browns filed a Rule
  59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment, generally disputing the
  assessment of attorneyâ€™s fees against them.[1]Â  The family court denied the motion.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of
  law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  When
  reviewing decisions of the family court, we are cognizant that the family court
  had the opportunity to see the witnesses, to hear â€œthe testimony delivered from
  the stand, and had the benefit of that personal observance of and contact with
  the parties which is of peculiar value in arriving at a correct result in a
  case of this character.â€Â  DuBose v.
    DuBose, 259
  S.C. 418, 423, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972) (internal citations omitted).Â  When
  the evidence is conflicting and susceptible of different inferences, the family
  court has the duty of determining not only the law of the case, but the facts
  as well, because it had
  the benefit of observing the witnesses and determining how much credence to
  give each witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  Anders v.
    Anders, 285
  S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322
  S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (holding when
  evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s
  findings).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
The Browns argue
  the family court abused its discretion in ordering them to pay part of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs.Â  Specifically, the Browns contend the family court erred
  because (1) Wife failed to plead attorneyâ€™s fees against them; (2) they were a
  third-party defendant; and (3) the fees were excessive.Â   
This
  issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Our review of the record reveals that
  the Browns did not raise these specific arguments to the family court.Â  At no
  time did the Browns object to the introduction of Wifeâ€™s evidence relating to attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs. Â The family court never ruled on these issues, and while the
  Browns briefly argued the fees were â€œpunitive in natureâ€ in their Rule 59(e),
  SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment, the remaining issues presented on
  appeal were not argued in the motion.Â  Further, counsel for the Browns conceded
  at oral argument that the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees was not raised at trial.Â  See In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be
  raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal,
  it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  Thus, the Brownsâ€™ failure to adequately raise these
  issues precludes review on appeal.Â   
II.Â  The House
The Browns contend the family court erred in finding
  they did not have an equitable interest in the House.Â  We disagree.
The
  family court has exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine actions â€œfor settlement of
  all legal and equitable rights of the parties in the actions in and to the real
  and personal property of the marriage . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(2)
  (Supp. 2006).Â  Section 20-7-473 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006)
  defines marital property as â€œall real and personal property which has been
  acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date
  of filing or commencement of marital litigation as provided in Â§ 20-7-472
  regardless of how legal title is held . . . .â€Â  However, â€œ[t]he court does not
  have jurisdiction or authority to apportion nonmarital property.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-473.
Section
  20-7-420(A)(19) grants the family court exclusive jurisdiction:

	to bring in and
      make parties to any proceedings pending in the court any person or persons . .
      . whose presence to the proceedings may be found necessary to a complete
      determination of the issues therein, or the relief to which the parties
      thereto, or any of them, may be entitled . . . .

â€œIn the past, subsection (19)
  has been construed to grant authority over third parties when property claimed
  to be marital was titled in a third partyâ€™s name.â€Â  Heape, 335 S.C. at
  423, 517 S.E.2d at 2 (citing Sexton v. Sexton, 298 S.C.
  359, 380 S.E.2d 832 (1989) (holding the family court has jurisdiction to
  join third parties when property is alleged to be marital but is owned by a
  third party)).
In
  the present case, the Wife sought an interest in the House, which was titled in
  Husbandâ€™s name, alleging it to be marital property.Â  The Browns asserted they
  were entitled to an equitable interest in the property because they made the
  $7,000 down payment on the House. Â Accordingly, because the Browns had a
  potential interest in the House, the family court properly made them parties to
  the divorce action to determine if the House was marital property.
The
  family court properly concluded the Browns had no legal interest in the House.Â  â€œBecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the
  witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad
  discretion.â€Â  Scott v. Scott, 354
  S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  In the present case, the family court found Husband and the Browns were not
  credible.Â  The Browns asserted Tojali, Inc., a company they founded for
  the benefit of Husband and his siblings, made the $7,000 down payment, thus
  entitling them to an equitable interest in the House.Â  However, the sole evidence
  corroborating the Brownsâ€™ testimony that Tojali, Inc., made the down payment
  was the testimony of Husband. Â Further, while the Browns claim they are
  entitled to an interest in the House, they never asserted ownership of the
  House during their bankruptcy proceedings.  
Additionally, Husband and Wife purchased the surrounding property and the House during
  their marriage. Â Both the contract to purchase the House and the title to the
  House and surrounding property were in Husbandâ€™s name.Â  Even if the Browns made
  the initial down payment, Wife testified that she and Husband used marital
  funds to make the mortgage payments and pay down the debt on the House.Â  While
  the Browns contributed with other family members to repairing and cleaning the House
  over the years, Wifeâ€™s brother-in-law testified Husband paid for the
  renovations to the House.Â Â  Accordingly, there is insufficient evidence to show
  the Browns made material contributions to the House that would entitle them to
  a special equity interest.Â  See Webber v. Webber, 285 S.C. 425, 427,
  330 S.E.2d 79, 80 (Ct. App. 1985) (stating under the special equity doctrine,
  â€œWhere [one] has made a material contribution to [anotherâ€™s] acquisition of
  property during [marriage], [that person] acquires a special equity in the
  property.â€) (internal citations omitted).  
Furthermore,
  in Hayne Federal Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 489 S.E.2d 472
  (1997), the Supreme Court was faced with the converse of this factual scenario.Â 
  There, the father initially failed to assert an interest in property deeded to
  and titled in his sonâ€™s name and only later claimed an interest in the property
  when creditors foreclosed on it. 327 S.C. at 252, 489 S.E.2d at 477.Â  The
  Supreme Court judicially estopped the father from asserting ownership in the
  house because in his prior divorce action, he claimed he had no legal interest
  in the property.Â  Id.Â  The Supreme Court reinforced its position
  stating, â€œWhen a party has formally asserted a certain version of the facts in
  litigation, he cannot later change those facts when the initial version no
  longer suits him.â€Â  Id.Â  In the present case, the Browns claim they are
  entitled to share in this marital asset, yet they did not list the House as an
  asset in their earlier bankruptcy proceedings.Â  Based on the evidence and
  the Brownsâ€™ position in the previous litigation, we find it would be
  inequitable to award the Browns an interest in the House.Â   
Therefore,
  we find the family court did not err in determining that the Browns did not have
  an equitable interest in the House.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the family courtâ€™s order is  
AFFIRMED.[2]
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The Brownsâ€™ argument on attorneyâ€™s fees in their
  59(e), SCRPP, motion was as follows:Â  â€œThe Courtâ€™s order requiring the Browns
  to pay half of [Wifeâ€™s expertâ€™s] fees and $5000.00 of [Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™] fees
  is punitive in nature based on the assumption that the Browns did not make
  these records available when in fact they did.â€Â   
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mehujael
      Romero, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Sylvester White
      and Christina White, Defendants,
				Of Whom
          Sylvester White is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â  Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-055
Heard December 11, 1007 â€“ Filed January
  14, 2008

REVERSED


	
		
			
				Douglas W. MacNeille, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				Terry L. Finger, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Sylvester
  White appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order granting specific performance to Mehujael
  Romero for the conveyance of a parcel of land located in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina.[1]Â  We reverse.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In
  1995, White and his wife acquired a one acre parcel of land designated as 70 Gum Tree Road (Gum Tree Lot), Hilton Head Island, South Carolina from Whiteâ€™s father.[2]Â 
  White never lived on the property, but stated his intention was for his
  children to inherit the property.Â  The surrounding land is still owned by
  members of Whiteâ€™s family.Â   
White
  first met Armando Garcia Uriostegi (Garcia), sometime in 1996 or 1997, when
  Garcia began renting a house next door to Whiteâ€™s.Â  According to White, shortly
  after meeting Garcia, the two discussed placing a trailer on the Gum Tree Lot.Â 
  Eventually, Garcia moved a trailer onto a quarter portion of the Gum Tree Lot.[3]Â   
Shortly
  after Garcia and his family moved onto the lot, White prepared a lease
  agreement[4] in which Garcia agreed to pay rent of $200 a month
  during a two year lease which commenced on September 3, 1999. According
  to White, the two had an informal agreement to extend the lease until 2004
  because Garcia was about to be incarcerated and wanted to make sure his family
  had a place to live.Â  Consequently, White stated he accepted a total of $15,000
  from Garcia for rent throughout the extended tenancy.Â  White also stated that
  at Garciaâ€™s request he provided Garcia with a receipt for the total amount of
  rent paid.Â  The writing White contends is the receipt states, â€œ[White] on
  10/10/00 received 15,000 from Garcia for payment for lot on Gum Tree R[oa]d.â€[5]Â 
  However, Romero contends the same document is a receipt for the sale of the Gum
  Tree Lot.[6]Â   
Romero brought suit seeking to enforce the alleged contract to
  convey real estate and specific performance for the conveyance of the Gum Tree
  Lot.Â  The assistance of a translator was required at trial since Romero does
  not speak English.Â  During the trial,
  Romero testified that at the time of the alleged oral agreement for the
  purchase of the Gum Tree Lot, she was present on the property but was not
  walking the property with Garcia and White when they set the boundary lines.Â  Due to this separation, Romero could not
  testify as to the size of the lot or the boundary lines.Â  Romero also testified
  her husband paid White $15,000 for the property and she knew this because
  â€œbefore [she and her husband paid] rent and then when they did the deal, that
  is when her husband told her he bought the property.â€ Upon this answer, defense
  counsel objected on the grounds of hearsay and the master struck Romeroâ€™s
  response insofar as the information told to Romero by her husband.  
After the bench trial concluded, the
  master ordered White to convey Romero the entire Gum Tree Lot.Â  Specifically,
  the master found the existence of an oral agreement for the sale of real estate
  and the writing indicating Whiteâ€™s receipt of $15,000 was sufficient to satisfy
  the Statute of Frauds, and, if not, there was sufficient part performance to
  remove the claim from the Statute of Frauds. This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an action in
  equity tried by the judge alone, on appeal the appellate court has jurisdiction
  to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C. 1, 4, 623 S.E.2d 833, 834 (2005); Campbell v. Carr, 361 S.C. 258, 263, 603 S.E.2d 625, 627 (Ct.
  App. 2004).Â  Thus, an appellate court in an appeal of an equity case tried
  without a jury may find facts in accord with its view of the preponderance or
  greater weight of the evidence and may reverse a factual finding by the trial
  judge in such cases where the appellant satisfies this court that the finding
  is against the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Campbell, 361 S.C. at
  263, 603 S.E.2d at 627.Â  This broad scope of review does not require the
  appellate court to disregard the findings of the trial court. Dearybury v.
    Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  Nor is the
  appellate court required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and
  heard the witnesses, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility.Â  Ingram
    v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 105, 531 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Statute of Frauds
White argues the Statute of Frauds bars the
  enforcement of the alleged oral agreement. Specifically, White contends no
  sufficient writing exists memorializing the alleged oral agreement.Â  We agree.Â  
 
The
  Statute of Frauds requires that a contract for the sale of land must be in
  writing and signed by the party against whom enforcement is sought. Â S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§32-3-10(4) (2006).Â  Failure to put such a contract in writing renders it
  void.Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891, 894
  (1989).Â  A writing sufficient to remove an oral agreement from the Statute of
  Frauds â€œmust reasonably identify the subject matter of the contract,
  sufficiently indicate a contract has been made between the parties, and state
  with reasonable certainty the essential terms of the agreement.â€ Id. (citing Restatement (Second) of Contracts, Â§ 131 (1981)).Â  Every essential
  element must be expressed in the writing for the contract to meet the Statute
  of Frauds. Cash v. Maddox, 265 S.C. 480, 484, 220 S.E.2d 121, 122
  (1975).Â   
The
  Statute of Frauds does not require any particular form of writing however, the
  writings must establish the essential terms of the contract without resort to
  parol evidence.Â  Id.Â  The identification of the land to be sold is one
  of the essential terms of a contract for sale of real property.Â  Id.Â  Although parol evidence may be used to explain terms appearing in a description
  of land, â€œthe description itself must clearly identify the particular parcel of
  land.â€ Id.Â  If a description of the land does not include the location
  or boundaries, it is inadequate. Fici v. Koon, 372 S.C. 341, 346-47, 642
  S.E.2d 602, 604-605 (2007). â€œWhere there is no adequate description of which
  part of a parcel is to be conveyed, the conveyance is unenforceable.â€ Id. at 347, 642 S.E.2d at 605. 
 
In Fici Buyer brought an action for specific performance of a contract for the sale of
  thirty acres of land.Â  The contract lists the property to be sold as â€œâ€˜lot 2,
  Polock Road, tax map #052000102â€™ in Irmo, Richland County,â€ but this
  description refers to the entire fifty acre parcel owned by Sellers. Id.Â  at 343, 642 S.E.2d at 603.Â  The contract specifies that the property conveyed
  will have â€œat least thirty acresâ€ and â€œpurchaser and seller will agree on
  location of property linesâ€ but Buyer and Sellers never agreed on the
  dimensions or location of the thirty acres among the entire fifty acre parcel.[7] Id.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court found the description did not
  show with reasonable certainty which thirty acres of the entire fifty acre
  parcel was to be conveyed.Â  Instead the supreme court found the contract was
  â€œnothing more than an agreement to agree which is unenforceable under the
  Statute of Frauds.â€ Id. at 347, 642 S.E.2d at 605.Â   
In
  regard to the necessary burden of proving an oral contract the supreme court
  has said, â€œ[w]e are not concerned primarily with the quantity of the evidence
  offered to establish the oral contract,â€¦[r]ather we are concerned more with the
  quality of the evidence.â€ Parr v. Parr, 268 S.C. 58, 65, 231 S.E.2d 695,
  698 (1977).Â  Clear, specific, definite evidence must convincingly prove the
  existence of the contract. Id.Â  Romero must â€œestablish the contract by
  â€˜competent and satisfactory proof, such as is clear, definite, and certain.â€™â€ Cash
    v. Maddox, 265 S.C. 480, 484, 220 S.E.2d 121, 122 (1975) (citing Aust v.
      Beard, 230 S.C. 515, 521, 96 S.E.2d 558, 561 (1957)).
In the case sub judice, the writing Romero relies upon to enforce the alleged oral
  agreement to convey real property is insufficient.Â  Although it is signed by
  White, the writing is unclear as to whether White intended to sell or rent the
  Gum Tree Lot to Garcia.Â  The master found Whiteâ€™s testimony on the matter
  lacked credibility because White pled guilty to possession of cocaine, a crime
  of moral turpitude.Â  Even if Whiteâ€™s testimony was discounted, we are still
  left with a nebulous writing which fails to specify whether it is referring to the entire Gum Tree Lot or only the
  one quarter portion Garcia rented in the past.Â  The writing also fails to
  identify the boundaries or state the size of the Gum Tree Lot.Â  Accordingly, we find there is no sufficient writing
  that satisfies the requirements of the Statute of Frauds.Â   
II. Existence of an Oral
  Agreement and 
Part Performance Exception to the Statute of Frauds
White
  argues the master erred in concluding the part performance exception to the
  Statute of Frauds was satisfied.Â  White maintains the only evidence of an oral
  agreement is Romeroâ€™s inadmissible hearsay statement.Â Â  We agree.  
In
  order for part performance of an oral agreement to remove the agreement from
  the Statute of Frauds and permit specific performance, Romero must establish
  acts that relate clearly to the agreement, exclusive of any other relation
  between the parties touching the agreement. Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C.
  101, 105-106, 382 S.E.2d 891, 894 (1989).Â  â€œPart performance may be proved by
  evidence of the following: (1) improvements to the real estate; (2) possession
  of the real estate; (3) payment of the purchase price.â€ Bradshaw v. Ewing, 297 S.C. 242, 245, 376 S.E.2d 264, 266 (1989).Â  For improvements to constitute
  part performance, they must be made by the purchaser with his own means upon
  the faith of the sellerâ€™s promise. Id. at 246, 376 S.E.2d at 266.Â  Such
  improvements must also be permanent and â€œof such a character as to enhance
  substantially the value of the property.â€ Id. at 246, 376 S.E.2d at 267.
  Payment of the purchase price is the weakest evidence of part performance and
  is not sufficient on its own to remove a contract from the Statute of Frauds. Id.Â  
 
Romero
  was not able to establish acts clearly relating to the alleged agreement for
  sale of the property that did not involve the partiesâ€™ prior rental agreement.Â 
  Much of Romeroâ€™s testimony regarding the terms of the oral contract was found
  to be hearsay because she was not present when the terms of any oral contract
  were being discussed.Â  Hearsay is a statement, other than one made by the
  declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to
  prove the truth of the matter asserted.Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  Hearsay is
  generally inadmissible. Rule 802, SCRE.Â   
Romero
  testified she was present on the property, but â€œshe was not walking with themâ€
  as the alleged contract was discussed between White and Garcia. In addition,
  Romero does not speak or understand English whereas White and Garcia discussed
  the alleged oral contract in English. Romero also testified Garcia purchased
  the property from White because â€œbefore they [paid] rent and then when they did
  the deal that is when her husband told her he bought the property.â€ White
  objected to this statement and the master struck the hearsay testimony â€œinsofar
  as what her husband said.â€Â   
Besides
  Romeroâ€™s stricken testimony, the record is devoid of any other evidence
  establishing a clear, unequivocal agreement for the sale of the Gum Tree Lot.Â 
  Romero also failed to provide evidence of part performance.Â  The only evidence
  of a permanent improvement to the Gum Tree Lot is the installation of a septic
  tank, initiated by White.Â  Neither Romero nor Garcia made any improvement to
  any portion of the Gum Tree Lot.Â  As to possession of the real property, Romero
  testified she and her family only rented a quarter of the lot prior to the
  alleged oral agreement for the sale of the land. Neither Romero nor Garcia paid
  property taxes for the Gum Tree Lot. Romero also testified the receipt was for
  the purchase of the Gum Tree Lot, but White testified it was for rental
  payments on a quarter portion of the lot. Even if we assume the $15,000 was for
  the purchase of the Gum Tree Lot, payment alone is not sufficient to remove the
  oral contract form the Statute of Frauds. Bradshaw, 297 S.C. at 245, 376
  S.E.2d at 266. Instead, there would need to be some other evidence exclusive of
  any prior lessor/lessee relationship between the parties. Player, 299
  S.C. at 105-106, 382 S.E.2d at 894.Â Â Â Â Â   
We
  find Romero failed to establish any clear, definite, and convincing evidence
  regarding the existence of an oral agreement between the parties.Â  In the
  absence of an oral agreement and without evidence upon which part performance
  could be found to support[8] a grant of specific performance, we must find the part performance exception to
  the Statute of Frauds does not apply.
Because
  we find no oral agreement, we need not address Whiteâ€™s remaining argument.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518
  S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining
  issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we find there is not an oral agreement
  to purchase the Gum Tree Lot.Â  Accordingly the decision of the master is
REVERSED. 
HEARN, C.J.,
  KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] The answer filed in this action purports to be filed
  on behalf of Sylvester White and his wife, Christina.Â  However, Christina White
  was adjudged to be in default.Â  The two separated sometime in 1999.Â   
[2] Whiteâ€™s deposition was taken de bene esse for use at trial pursuant to Rule 30, SCRCP.Â  At the time of the deposition,
  White was incarcerated for cocaine related charges to which he had pled
  guilty.Â  The master found Whiteâ€™s testimony lacked credibility because White
  pled guilty to possession of cocaine, a crime of moral turpitude.Â   
[3] White stated he planned on dividing the one acre lot
  into four parcels as rentals.Â   
[4] The lease refers to Lot One, not a quarter portion of
  the Gum Tree Lot.Â  Garcia and Mehujael Romero, his wife, lived on the Gum Tree
  Lot until Garcia was incarcerated, and then Romero remained on the property
  with their children.  
[5] According to White, this receipt was for late and
  future rent for the quarter of the Gum Tree Lot on which the trailer was
  located.  
[6] Garcia signed over all of his interests in his
  property to Romero.Â   
[7] A surveyor drew up two versions of a plat denoting
  the proposed property lines of the thirty acres.Â  Buyer signed the second plat
  but Sellers never agreed to the property lines on either plat.
[8] For a court of equity to compel specific performance
  of an oral agreement where part performance is alleged to have removed the
  contract from the Statute of Frauds, the court â€œmust find: (1) clear evidence
  of an oral agreement; (2) the agreement had been partially executed; and (3)
  the party who requested performance had completed or was willing to complete
  his part of the oral agreement.â€ Settlemeyer v. McCluney, 359 S.C. 317,
  320, 596 S.E.2d 514, 516 (Ct. App. 2004).

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

-->




THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				BP Staff, Inc., Appellant,
				v.
				Capital City Insurance Company, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Unknown County
Ralph K. Anderson, III, Administrative Law Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-060
Heard December 12, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  16, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				D. Randle Moody, II, and Â Ellison F.
  McCoy, both of
				Greenville, for Appellant.
				Mark Aloysius Cullen, of W. Palm Beach,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: At issue in this appeal is the application
  of an experience modifier rating to Appellant BP Staff in the workersâ€™
  compensation insurance policy issued by Capital City Insurance Company.Â  The Administrative Law Court upheld the decision by the Department of Insurance to support the
  application of S.B. Phillipsâ€™ experience modifier rating to BP Staff.Â  BP Staff
  appeals the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s ruling on the ground that S.B. Phillips
  and BP Staff are separate entities owned respectively by father and son.Â  We
  affirm the ruling of the Administrative Law Court.
FACTS
S.B.
  Phillips is a temporary staffing agency founded in Greenville in 1968 and owned
  by Sam Phillips. Blanton Phillips, Sam Phillipsâ€™ son, worked for S.B. Phillips
  for several years in numerous positions until he eventually was â€œrunning most
  of the back office operations of the business, accounting and payroll and risk
  management.â€ Blanton primarily handled workers compensation for S.B. Phillips.
  In July of 2002, Blanton formed BP Staff, Inc. which provided â€œpayroll,
  staffing, risk management, and other related servicesâ€ to companies. Blanton is
  the sole owner of BP Staff. 
In
  September 2002, BP Staff and S.B. Phillips entered into an agreement whereby BP
  Staff would hire the temporary workers of S.B. Phillips, perform payroll
  functions for those workers, and provide workersâ€™ compensation for those
  workers. In essence, BP Staff would hire S.B. Phillips temporary employees and
  perform the same â€œback officeâ€ services for those temporary employees as
  Blanton himself had performed while working with S.B. Phillips. The temporary
  workers would still be provided to S.B. Phillips for placement in temporary
  positions with S.B. Phillipsâ€™ clients as the workers had been in the past.
  After the agreement S.B. Phillips essentially eliminated the in-house
  performance of â€œback officeâ€ functions such as risk management while still
  performing the â€œfront officeâ€ services of sales, recruiting, and customer
  service. Some of BP Staffâ€™s permanent employees were previously employed by S.B.
  Phillips. As late as 2004, permanent employees of BP Staff remained on S.B.
  Phillipsâ€™ payroll but were â€œassigned to BP Staff.â€ 
In
  September 2002, S.B. Phillips and BP Staff each applied for workersâ€™
  compensation insurance through South Carolinaâ€™s Assigned Risk Pool after they
  were unable to secure coverage in the voluntary insurance market. South Carolinaâ€™s Department of Insurance (Department) forwarded the applications to Capital
  City Insurance Company (Capital City), one of two carriers in the Assigned Risk
  Pool. After reviewing BP Staffâ€™s application, Capital City issued a policy for
  BP Staff with a 1.33 experience modifier rating (Modifier).Â  Experience
  modifier ratings (Modifier) are factors calculated using a complex formula
  developed by the National Council on Compensation Insurance (NCCI).[1]Â 
  NCCI also produces an experience rating plan manual (Plan Manual) that sets
  forth the rules governing the application of Modifiers to different entities
  applying for workersâ€™ compensation insurance. Once approved by the Department
  of Insurance, the Plan Manual sets forth the rules regarding insurance coverage
  in the Assigned Risk Pool. 
Modifiers
  are factors which affect the total cost of an entityâ€™s premium. Under the Plan
  Manual, new companies applying for workerâ€™s compensation insurance receive a
  neutral Modifier of one. If an insured has a history of above-normal claims for
  their type of industry, the insuredâ€™s Modifier would increase and thus cause an
  increase in the overall premium. The Modifier system provides an incentive for
  employers to provide a safe workplace. Insurance carriers traditionally
  consider temporary staffing agencies to be a high-risk business. 
In
  its determination to apply the 1.33 Modifier of S.B. Phillips to BP Staff, Capital City reviewed the Plan Manual and information provided by S.B. Phillips and BP
  Staff before concluding the Modifier should follow the employees that created
  the experience. BP Staffâ€™s request for reconsideration of the Modifier was
  granted by Capital City but the decision to apply S.B. Phillipsâ€™ modifier to BP
  Staff was not altered.Â  BP Staff appealed Capital Cityâ€™s imposition of a 1.33 Modifier
  to NCCI and then the South Carolina Department of Insurance.Â  The Department
  held an evidentiary hearing on October 14, 2004, after which it ruled in favor
  of Capital City. 
BP
  Staff subsequently appealed the Departmentâ€™s findings to the Administrative Law
  Court (ALC) on August 5, 2005. On August 23, 2006, the ALC upheld the
  Departmentâ€™s findings, specifically the interpretation of the Plan Manual, the
  evidence in support of applying the 1.33 Modifier to BP Staff, the sufficiency
  of the Departmentâ€™s findings, and the denial of BP Staffâ€™s request to reopen
  the record and admit a letter issued by NCCI subsequent to the Departmentâ€™s
  hearing. BP Staff filed notice to appeal with this court on September 22, 2006. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
As
  revised by Act 387 in 2006, South Carolina Code Section 1-23-380 sets forth the
  standard of review when the court of appeals is sitting in review of a decision
  by the Administrative Law Court on an appeal from an administrative agency.Â 
  Section 1-23-380(A)(5) forbids the court of appeals from substituting â€œits
  judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on
  questions of fact.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (2006).Â  The court of
  appeals may reverse or modify the decision only if substantial rights of the
  appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative decision is clearly
  erroneous in light of the reliable and substantial evidence on the whole
  record, arbitrary or otherwise characterized by an abuse of discretion, or
  affected by other error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d)-(f) (2006).Â 
  â€œThe review of the administrative law judgeâ€™s order must be confined to the
  record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(C) (2006). 
The
  Departmentâ€™s decision can be set aside if it is unsupported by substantial
  evidence.Â  Hamm v. Central States Health & Life Co., 292 S.C.
  408, 410, 357 S.E.2d 5, 6 (1987); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C.
  130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981).Â  â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€
  is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one
  side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole,
  would allow reasonable minds to
  reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached.Â  Taylor v.
    S.C. Depâ€™t of Motor Vehicles, 368 S.C. 33, 36, 627 S.E.2d 751,
  752 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. granted, Aug. 9, 2007; S.C. Coastal
    Conservation League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 363 S.C.
  67, 76, 610 S.E.2d 482, 487 (2005).
The
  party challenging a governmental bodyâ€™s decision bears the burden of proving
  the decision is arbitrary.Â  Pressley v. Lancaster County, 343 S.C. 696,
  704, 542 S.E.2d 366, 370 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Appellants also shoulder the
  burden of proving an agencyâ€™s decision is unsupported by evidence.Â  Bursey
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 142, 600 S.E.2d
  80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004), affâ€™d, 369 S.C. 176, 631 S.E.2d 899 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Experience
  Rating Plan Manual
BP Staff argues the Administrative Law Court improperly considered the Plan Manual.Â 
  This argument is not preserved for our review.
BP Staff did not contest either the Departmentâ€™s or the ALCâ€™s
  treatment of the Plan Manual as â€œthe applicable governing document concerning
  the issues in this case.â€ In fact, BP Staff concedes in numerous briefs that â€œthe terms of the 1984 Plan Manual contain all rules
  applicable to this dispute.â€ In their brief to the ALC, BP Staff uses the term
  â€œregulationâ€[2] when referring to the Plan Manual and presses the court to utilize the rules of
  statutory construction in interpreting the Plan Manual. 
An issue not ruled upon by antecedent trial courts is not
  preserved for appeal. West v. Newberry
    Electric Coop., 357 S.C. 537, 543,
  593 S.E.2d 500, 503 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding an issue neither addressed by the
  trial judge in the final order nor mentioned in a subsequent motion for
  reconsideration is not preserved for review); Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330
  S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is
  axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must
  have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for
  appellate review.â€).Â  In addition, a party cannot argue one ground at trial and
  an alternate ground on appeal. State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587
  S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003).
II. Â Â Â Â  Part
  III(B) of the Experience Rating Plan Manual
BP Staff argues the Administrative Law Court erred in holding the
  list in Part III(B) of the Plan Manual is not a restrictive enumeration of the actions
  that cause the experience modification rating of one entity to be applied to another
  entity.Â  We disagree.
Part III(B) of the Plan Manual involves ownership changes which
  may affect the Modifier bestowed upon an entity.Â  Part III(B) explains â€œwhen a
  change occurs, a determination shall be made to exclude or retain an entityâ€™s
  experience.â€ Part III(B) further states:

	For purposes of this Plan, a change in ownership includes any of the following:
	(a) Sale, transfer or conveyance of all or a portion of an
  entityâ€™s ownership interest.
	(b) Sale, transfer or conveyance of an entityâ€™s physical assets to another entity which takes over its operations.
	(c) Merger or consolidation of two or more entities.
	(d) Formation of a new entity subsequent to the dissolution or non-operative capacity of an entity.
	(e) Voluntary or court-mandated establishment of a trustee or receiver, excluding a debtor in possession, a trustee under a revocable trust or a franchisor. 
	

In determining the nature of the list in Part III(B) the ALC first
  employed rules of statutory construction and dictionary definitions of
  â€œinclude.â€Â  â€œWhere a word is not defined in a statute, our appellate courts
  have looked to the usual dictionary meaning to supply its meaning.â€ Lee v.
    Thermal Engineering Corp., 352 S.C. 81, 91-92, 572 S.E.2d 298, 303 (Ct.
  App. 2002); State v. Dickinson, 339 S.C. 194, 199, 528 S.E.2d 675, 677
  (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary for the definition of
  â€œobtainingâ€ used in a statute for obtaining property in fraudulent manner).Â 
  The ALC quoted the third edition of the American Heritage Dictionary of the
  English Language and Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, the latter of which defines
  â€œincludeâ€ as â€œto contain as part of something.â€ Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary (8th ed. 2004 and 6th ed. 1990). 
On appeal, BP Staff makes a conclusory argument that â€œnone of the[se] definitions of the word
  â€œincludesâ€ provide[s] any guidance as to whether the list contained in Part
  III(B) of the Plan Manual is exclusive in nature.â€ Failure to provide arguments
  or supporting authority for an issue renders it abandoned. First Savings Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994).Â  
The
  ALC also used case law to determine the nature of the list in Part III(B),
  specifically, how other courts have interpreted the term â€œinclude.â€Â  BP Staff
  argues the ALC incorrectly cited three cases that allegedly utilize the term
  â€œincludeâ€ in a manner to indicate a partial list. In its order the ALC referred
  to Adkins v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 360 S.C. 413, 602 S.E.2d 51 (2004), Douglass ex rel. Louthian v. Boyce, 344 S.C. 5, 542 S.E.2d 715 (2001), and Reliance Ins.
    Co. v. Smith, 327 S.C. 528, 489 S.E.2d 674 (Ct. App. 1997), as appellate
  decisions that have employed an expansive interpretation of â€œinclude.â€ Louthian, Adkins, and Reliance respectively involve the South Carolina
  Probate Code, the state prison system, and state agency rulemaking.Â  While none
  of these cases define â€œinclude,â€ they all illustrate courtsâ€™ usage of â€œincludeâ€
  in an expansive manner.Â  For example, in Louthian the South
  Carolina Supreme Court found that â€œother fiduciary
  propertyâ€ as used in Section 62-1-109 of the South Carolina Probate Code
  includes the proceeds of a wrongful death action since such an action is
  brought by a fiduciary.Â  Such proceeds were not expressly enumerated in any
  definition of â€œother fiduciary property.â€ 344 S.C. at 10, 542 S.E.2d at
  717-18.Â  The supreme court has also held simply because a matter is not
  expressly mentioned in a list does not mean that matter is forbidden or
  restricted from an agencyâ€™s reach.Â  S.C. Coastal Conservation League v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 354 S.C. 585, 588-89, 582 S.E.2d 410,
  412 (2003).Â  
Appellant fails to prove the ALCâ€™s holding regarding the
  Department of Insuranceâ€™s interpretation of Part III(B) of the Plan Manual is
  arbitrary, characterized by an abuse of discretion, or otherwise affected an
  error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5)(d)-(f) (2006);Â  Â First Savings Bank, 314
  S.C. at 363, 444 S.E.2d at 514 (â€œMere allegations of error are
  not sufficient to demonstrate an abuse of discretion.â€)Â  Accordingly we find no
  reason exists to reverse or modify the ALCâ€™s holding.
III.Â Â Â  Substantial
  Evidence
BP
  Staff argues the record is devoid of substantial evidence to support the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s ruling regarding the application of a 1.33 experience modifier rating to BP Staff.Â  We disagree.
The record is replete with evidence indicating BP Staff and S.B.
  Phillips have a unique relationship which justifies the application of S.B.
  Phillipsâ€™ Modifier to BP Staffâ€™s policy of workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  
Neither
  Sam nor Blanton Phillips has any ownership in the otherâ€™s company, but S.B.
  Phillips and BP Staff have a unique relationship.Â  S.B. Phillips was BP Staffâ€™s
  first client. Pursuant to a 2002 contract, BP Staff hired the temporary
  employees of S.B. Phillips and provides those temporary employees back to S.B.
  Phillips for S.B. Phillips to place in employment. Under the contract BP Staff
  provides the payroll and workersâ€™ compensation for those employees as well as
  risk management for that group of S.B. Phillipsâ€™ employees. Approximately 80
  employees remained at S.B. Phillips following the institution of the contract.
  These employees handle the â€œfront officeâ€ services of sales, recruitment, and
  placement of temporary employees. 
Although
  BP Staff has over two thousand employees, only four of those employees are
  permanent or non-temporary employees. The four permanent employees work in Greenville in the same office building where S.B. Phillips is located. In the first ten
  months following BP Staffâ€™s inception, S.B. Phillips provided approximately
  ninety-seven percent of BP Staffâ€™s payroll. BP Staff and S.B. Phillips also
  applied for workersâ€™ compensation coverage in an assigned risk plan at
  approximately the same time. 
Dwayne Schumpert, an underwriter at Capital City Insurance,
  reviewed BP Staffâ€™s and S.B. Phillipsâ€™ applications for insurance coverage as
  part of South Carolinaâ€™s Assigned Risk Pool.[3]Â 
  To Schumpert it â€œappeared that there had been a new company set up so that they
  would have the temporary portion and then S.B. had the permanent employees.â€
  From the information both companies supplied, it was clear the payroll of S.B.
  Phillips had been moved to BP Staff resulting in an initial payroll of 20
  million dollars as soon as BP Staff was formed.
Schumpert also believed BP Staff and S.B. Phillips were related
  due to the similarities in both companiesâ€™ applications. Although the
  applications were in separate envelopes, the envelopes were addressed in the
  same manner and were received on the same day. The applications requested the
  same effective date, expiration date, and limits as well as two types of
  coverage that are rarely requested. Both applications listed the same three
  insurance companies as proof of rejection from the voluntary market.[4] Identical portions of the
  applications were blank and both applications listed Kara deBorde as the person
  responsible for handling claims information. The identical nature of the
  applications caused Schumpert to believe the same individuals had filled out
  each companyâ€™s application for coverage. 
Each application also had notations regarding the coverage they
  were requesting. The S.B. Phillipsâ€™ application explained â€œwe are not seeking
  coverage for temporary employeesâ€ but that coverage was requested only for
  permanent, administrative staff. Likewise the BP Staff application noted,
  â€˜[t]his application is for coverage for temporary employees only.â€ The drug
  policy information BP Staff provided to Capital City was faxed with a cover
  letter indicating it was a policy for BP Staff but many of the individual,
  substantive pages explaining the drug policy referred to S.B. Phillips or
  Phillips Staffing. 
Due to these similarities Schumpert applied the 1.33 Modifier of S.B.
  Phillips to the workersâ€™ compensation insurance policy of BP Staff.Â  When
  Schumpertâ€™s decision was further reviewed by Paula Shields at NCCI and Dean
  Kruger at the South Carolina Department of Insurance, both came to the same
  conclusion that S.B. Phillipsâ€™ Modifier should follow the employees to BP Staff
  which was operating as in-concert with S.B. Phillips as a successor-type
  company. BP Staff had â€œthe same operations, the same clients, the same
  employeesâ€ as S.B. Phillips. At the Department of Insurance hearing, Blanton
  admitted BP Staff and S.B. Phillips operate in-concert and share employees. 
In addition, when dealing with the South Carolina Employment Security
  Commission BP Staff had claimed it was a successor to S.B. Phillips and as a
  successor, â€œshould have received a successor number and predecessor rate.â€ BP
  Staffâ€™s report to the South Carolina Employment Security Commission further
  states that â€œexempt wages [are] covered under predecessorâ€™s employers.â€ 
The
  Department of Insuranceâ€™s decision can be set aside if it is unsupported by
  substantial evidence. Hamm v. Central States Health & Life Co.,
  292 S.C. 408, 410, 357 S.E.2d 5, 6 (1987).Â  The possibility of drawing two
  inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s
  finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 369 S.C. 176, 188, 631 S.E.2d 899,
  906 (2006). The credibility and weight of a witnessâ€™s testimony is for the
  trier of fact.Â  Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 67, 456 S.E.2d
  366, 368 (1995).Â  In light of the evidence presented in the record, we
  find substantial evidence supports the ALCâ€™s finding that the Department of
  Insuranceâ€™s determination that S.B. Phillipsâ€™ Modifier should apply to BP
  Staff.
IV.Â Â Â  Supplementation of
  the Record
BP
  Staff argues the Administrative Law Court improperly ruled the Department of Insurance did not commit an error of law
  when the Department refused to allow cumulative supplemental evidence into the
  record following the conclusion of the evidentiary hearing.Â  We
  disagree.
After the Departmentâ€™s evidentiary hearing concluded, BP Staff
  sought to admit a November 3, 2004 letter issued by Wendy Steinberg, an employee
  in NCCIâ€™s Experience Rating Department, that states â€œS.B. Phillips and BP Staff
  Inc. are not combinable with each other.â€ BP Staff was unsuccessful in arguing
  the Department should admit the letter into the record. The ALC upheld the
  Departmentâ€™s decision and found such a decision â€œto reopen an administrative
  record for additional evidence is within the Departmentâ€™s sound discretion and
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.â€ Brenco v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 363 S.C. 136, 145, 609 S.E.2d 531, 536 (Ct. App.
  2005). 
BP Staff argued in their pre-hearing brief to the ALC that S.B.
  Phillips and BP Staff were not combinable. During the Departmentâ€™s hearing,
  evidence was presented that NCCI initially held BP Staff and S.B. Phillips were
  not combinable. In the post-hearing brief to the Department, BP acknowledges
  that â€œduring the October 14 hearing, two NCCI officials testified that BP Staff
  and S.B. Phillips were not combinable.â€ 
Through
  BP Staffâ€™s own admissions, the letter stating BP Staff and S.B. Phillips are
  not combinable is cumulative to the evidence already in the record. â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its
  probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice,
  confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue
  delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€ Rule 403, SCRE.Â  In
  addition, BP Staff has made no showing that the additional evidence of the
  November 3 letter would result in a changed outcome. â€œTo warrant reversal based
  on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the
  error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice.â€ Wright v. Craft, 372
  S.C. 1, 34, 640 S.E.2d 486, 504 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Accordingly we find no error
  of law or abuse of discretion by the ALC in upholding the Department of
  Insuranceâ€™s decision not to reopen the record. 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., THOMAS, J., and GOOLSBY,
    A.J., concur.

[1] NCCI is a rating organization that collects data from
  carriers and provides statistical and rating information on workerâ€™s
  compensation and employee injuries to several states, including South Carolina.
 
[2] Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œregulationâ€ to be â€œ1)
  The act or process of controlling by rule or restriction; 2) Bylaw; 3) A rule
  or order, having legal force, usually issued by an administrative agency.â€ (8th ed. 2004).
[3] When companies cannot obtain insurance coverage in
  the voluntary market, they may apply for coverage under South Carolinaâ€™s
  Assigned Risk Pool. Applications for coverage under this program are split
  between Capital City Insurance and Companion Insurance. By chance both BP
  Staffâ€™s application and SB Phillipsâ€™ application were forwarded to Capital City. Schumpert noted that insurance companies traditionally think of temporary
  staffing as a high risk enterprise so many temporary staffing companies end up
  seeking coverage in a residual market such as South Carolinaâ€™s Assigned Risk
  Pool.  
[4] To gain coverage in the Assigned Risk Pool, companies
  must demonstrate their applications for coverage have been rejected by at least
  two insurance carriers in the voluntary market.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Johnny Ray
          Gambrell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-063
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January
22, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General
          John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka; Assistant
          Attorney General J. Anthony Mabry, of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina Theos
          Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Johnny
  Ray Gambrell appeals his murder conviction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS

Gambrell
  and Lois Gambrell were married and lived in a rental house on Mahaffey Street in Belton.Â  Their marriage was tumultuous and Lois was allegedly
  hospitalized after Gambrell beat her.Â  The parties separated on at least one
  occasion.Â  On another occasion, Lois asked Shane Garner, the landlord, to
  change the locks as Gambrell would be vacating the house. Â One day in June of
  2004, Gambrell told Garner he believed Lois was â€œrunning aroundâ€ on him.Â  The
  following night, Gambrell allegedly told Garner he had severely beat Lois.Â  After
  each incident, the parties reconciled.Â  
On July
  12 and 13 of 2004, Lois visited her mother, who was recuperating from surgery,
  but Lois did not show up to visit her mother, as expected, on July 14, 2004.Â  The
  Gambrellâ€™s neighbors and Garner testified they last saw Lois at the marital
  home approximately July 15, 2004.Â  On July 16, 2004, Garner visited the house
  to collect rent at approximately 9:30 or 10:00 p.m.Â  Gambrell did not answer
  the door but eventually came around the side of the house.Â  Garner testified
  Gambrell appeared nervous and sweaty.Â  That same evening, Gambrell built a
  large bonfire.Â  One neighborhood teenager estimated Gambrell started the fire
  at approximately 8:00 or 9:00 p.m.Â  Another neighborhood teenager noticed the
  fire after he got off work at either 9:00 or 10:00 p.m. that evening.Â  Garner
  did not notice the fire when he visited Gambrell.Â  He testified, however, he
  saw Gambrell at approximately 4:00 a.m. the following morning, tending the
  large bonfire.Â  
Gambrell moved out of the house the following day.Â  Garner
  testified Gambrell told him that Lois had come to the house, taken all of her
  things, and left.Â  Gambrell told Garner he thought Lois was staying in a hotel
  in Anderson.Â  Garner testified the inside of the house was trashed with debris
  and evidence of a fight.Â  There was also a spot on the carpet that looked like
  blood.Â  Garner and his family cleaned the house and shampooed the carpet.Â  There
  were numerous personal items left in the house including â€œwomanâ€™s baloney . . .
  [such as] clothes, womenâ€™s deodorant, razors, [and] womenâ€™s products.Â  Stuff
  like that.â€Â  Garner and his family members also cleaned the bonfire debris,
  taking most of it to a landfill.Â  When Garner ran out of garbage bags, he
  shoveled the remaining debris into garbage barrels in the back yard.Â  Garner
  found numerous articles in the debris including Loisâ€™s birth certificate and
  Social Security card.Â  
Loisâ€™s mother and sister reported Lois missing on or about August
  23, 2004.Â  City of Anderson Detective James Stewart investigated the missing
  personâ€™s report.Â  Stewart testified Gambrell reported he had not seen Lois in
  three months.Â  Officer Jamie Brothers also testified Gambrell told him he had
  not seen Lois in three months.Â  Brothers further testified Gambrell said he
  thought Lois was in Texas with a family member.Â  
The police investigated and recovered bone fragments in the garbage
  barrels.Â  Around the burn area, the police also found Loisâ€™s jewelry and glasses
  and other metal items such as car keys, zippers, and buttons.Â  Inside the house,
  the police found the blood stain but were unable to identify the blood as human
  blood.Â  
The bone fragments were identified by a forensic anthropologist as
  belonging to a woman approximately forty years old and five foot four inches in
  height.Â  Loisâ€™s mother testified Lois was approximately 43 years old at the
  time she disappeared.Â  The bone fragments were also identified, through DNA
  comparison of Loisâ€™s mother, as belonging to an offspring of Loisâ€™s mother.Â  
Gary
  Bean, an arson investigation expert, visited the site and testified he noticed
  the smell of a burned body.Â  Bean opined the bonfire burned between 10 and 12
  feet in diameter at a temperature, between 1000 and 1300 degrees Fahrenheit,
  sufficient to burn a human body.Â  A forensic chemist testified a heavy
  petroleum accelerant such as kerosene or diesel fuel started the fire.Â  Neighbors
  testified Gambrell fed the fire with books and clothes.Â  In the debris after the
  fire, there was evidence that tires, a mattress, and living room furniture were
  also burned.Â  Â Â 
Christopher
  Wickware, a car salesman, testified he sold Lois a Chevrolet Cavalier and later
  hired a company to repossess the vehicle.Â  The payments were subsequently made
  and the car returned to Wickwareâ€™s dealership lot between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00
  a.m. one night in August of 2004.Â  The car was trashed, as if it had been
  outside for a period of time with the windows down.Â  
The jury convicted
  Gambrell of murder and the trial court sentenced Gambrell to life
  imprisonment.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS

I. Directed Verdict
Gambrell argues
  the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We
  disagree.
When ruling on a
  motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence
  or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight. State v.
    Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002).Â  This court must review
  the denial of a directed verdict by reviewing the evidence and all reasonable
  inferences in the light most favorable to the State. Â State v. Burdette,
  335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999). Â This court must affirm the denial
  of an accusedâ€™s motion for a direct verdict if there is any direct evidence or
  any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt
  of the accused. Â State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273
  (2002).Â  The standard of review is the same where the State relies exclusively
  on circumstantial evidence.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593-94, 606
  S.E.2d 475, 477-78 (2004).
In this case, the
  State presented substantial circumstantial evidence of Gambrellâ€™s guilt.Â  Murder
  is defined as the â€œkilling of any person with malice aforethought, either
  express or implied.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-10 (2003).Â  There are numerous
  facts supporting the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion for a directed verdict.
Gambrell and Lois
  had a stormy relationship and Gambrell physically harmed Lois on prior
  occasions.Â  Garner and other witnesses observed Lois at the marital home within
  a day or two of the bonfire.Â  Gambrell made conflicting statements as to the
  last time he had seen Lois.Â  Witnesses observed Gambrell at or near the bonfire
  at various times as it burned.Â  Bones found in the bonfire debris were
  identified as belonging to an offspring of Loisâ€™s mother.Â  See State
    v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 411-13, 578 S.E.2d 32, 34-36 (Ct. App. 2003)
  (Concealment or attempted destruction of the body of a murdered person is a
  probative fact tending to show guilt.). Â Other items belonging to Lois were
  found near the burn site.Â  Loisâ€™s vehicle was mysteriously returned to the car
  dealership near the time the investigation into Loisâ€™s disappearance began.Â  Taken
  together, these facts constitute substantial circumstantial evidence presented
  by the State to warrant submission of the case to the jury.Â  The motion for a
  directed verdict was properly denied.
II. Motion for Mistrial
Gambrell next
  argues the trial court erred in refusing his motion for a mistrial based on
  Officer Stewartâ€™s statement on cross-examination.Â  We disagree.Â  
During
  cross-examination, defense
  counsel questioned Stewart about Gambrellâ€™s alleged statement that he had not
  seen Lois in three months.Â  Defense counsel asked:Â  â€œCould it have been that he
  said [he] hadnâ€™t seen her in three or four weeks . . . ?â€Â  Stewart replied:Â 
  â€œNo, sir.Â  I am certain on that.Â  I was walking back to the control booth at
  the Anderson County Detention Center.â€Â  The State briefly redirected and
  defense counsel moved for a mistrial.Â  Defense counsel declined the trial
  courtâ€™s offer of a curative instruction.Â  
We find
  Gambrell waived this issue by declining the curative instruction.Â  See State v. Watts, 321 S.C. 158, 164-65, 467 S.E.2d 272, 276 (Ct. App.
  1996) (finding defendant waived issue by rejecting offer by trial court to give
  a curative instruction).
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  Gambrellâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Butts v. C.R. England Trucking
text:
