THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        William Butts, Appellant,
        v.
        C.R. England
          Trucking and Cambridge Integrated Services Group Inc., Defendants,
        
        Of Whom C.R.
          England Trucking is the 
          Respondent.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-064
Heard December 11, 2007 â€“ Filed January
22, 2008

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        E. Courtney Gruber and R. Walter Hundley, both of Charleston, for
          Appellant.
        Clarke W. McCants, III, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  William Butts appeals a circuit court order affirming the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s determination that Butts was not totally and
  permanently disabled after suffering a work-related injury.Â  The essence of
  Buttsâ€™ appeal is that the combined
  effects of his pre-existing psychological condition and his subsequent injury
  resulted in a greater disability than he would have experienced from the injury
  alone, resulting in his inability to work and complete disability under S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-400 (1985 & Supp. 2006).Â  In light of the recent decision
  from our supreme court in Ellison v. Frigidaire Home Products, 371 S.C.
  159, 638 S.E.2d 664 (2006), we agree with Butts that the Commission imposed an
  inappropriate legal standard in evaluating the effects and relationship of his
  pre-existing injury to his subsequent work-related injury.Â  Accordingly, we reverse
  and remand to the circuit court, which shall remand the matter to the
  Commission with instructions to consider Buttsâ€™ claim under the Ellison standard.Â  
I.
William
  Butts sustained an admitted workersâ€™ compensation injury to his lower back on
  November 7, 2000 while working for C.R. England Trucking as a truck driver.Â 
  According to Butts, he heard a snap in his back when he picked up a pallet
  while working on a long-distance trucking assignment.Â  England Trucking paid
  some of Buttsâ€™ medical bills and also paid him temporary compensation for the
  back injury.Â  Butts thereafter contended his back injury aggravated his
  pre-existing psychological condition of post-traumatic stress disorder.[1]Â 
  Butts alleged he was permanently and totally disabled as a result of the
  combined effects of his accident and psychological condition and sought
  lifetime medical benefits.Â Â Â  
In an order filed
  March 4, 2003, the single commissioner found Butts had lost more than fifty
  percent of the use of his back as a result of the accident, in combination with
  his pre-existing arthritis, and that the accident had aggravated his
  pre-existing post-traumatic stress disorder.Â  The single commissioner found
  Butts was permanently and totally disabled and ruled he was entitled to
  lifetime medical benefits.Â  
England Trucking
  sought review of the single commissionerâ€™s order by the Commission.Â  In a
  decision filed January 13, 2004, the Commission found Butts had suffered an
  injury to his lower back, but reversed the single commissionerâ€™s determination
  that the injury resulted in the aggravation of a pre-existing psychological
  condition.Â  The Commission found Butts was entitled to compensation for a ten
  percent, permanent, partial disability to his lower back as a result of the
  accident.Â  Â Â 
Butts appealed to the circuit court, which remanded
  the matter to the Commission â€œto state with specificity the evidence upon which
  its decision is based.â€Â  The circuit court stated there was evidence in the
  record which â€œclearlyâ€ supported the original finding of the single
  commissioner that Butts suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder, which
  â€œboth pre-existed and was aggravated by the work-related accident.â€Â  The circuit
  court observed that neither England Trucking nor the Commission had cited to
  any specific medical evidence to support the findings of the Commission
  regarding Buttsâ€™ claim.Â  Â Â 
Upon
  remand, the Commission issued an order filed March 15, 2005 that more fully set
  forth the reasons for its decision.Â  The Commission found Butts sustained an
  injury to his back as a result of a work-related accident, but that Butts â€œdid
  not sustain any other permanent injury to any other part of his body as a
  result of the accident . . . and did not sustain any psychological injury, or
  aggravation to a pre-existing psychological condition as a result of said
  accident.â€Â  The Commission further found that Butts â€œsuffered from significant
  psychological and physical problems which existed before the accident in this
  caseâ€ and â€œthat any inability of [Butts] to engage in any employment activities
  is not due to any injury sustained by him while working for [England
  Trucking].â€Â Â Â  
The
  Commission awarded Butts benefits for a ten percent, permanent, partial
  disability to his lower back pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30 (1985 &
  Supp. 2006), the scheduled injury statute, and authorized payment for all
  causally related and authorized medical treatment for the injury to his lower
  back.Â  Butts sought a review of this decision.Â  The circuit court, with a
  different judge presiding, upheld the decision of the Commission by order filed
  July 20, 2006.Â  Butts appeals.
II.
In this case we are presented with conflicting views
  on the appropriate scope of review.Â  Butts contends the Commission applied the
  wrong legal standard in denying his claim that he was totally disabled.Â  He
  further contends the circuit court improperly found substantial evidence
  supported the Commissionâ€™s determination because application of the wrong legal
  standard affected the Commissionâ€™s determination.Â  In contrast, England
  Trucking argues the Commissionâ€™s fact-based determination should not be
  reversed because it is supported by substantial evidence.Â  
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes
  the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Commission.Â  West v. Alliance Capital, 368 S.C. 246, 628 S.E.2d 279 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Under the APA, an appellate court may reverse or modify the
  decision of the agency if the agencyâ€™s findings, inferences, conclusions, or
  decisions are affected by an error of law or are clearly erroneous in view of
  the substantial evidence in the whole record.Â  Id.; see also S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (Supp. 2006).Â  Substantial evidence is evidence that,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion reached by the Commission.Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp.,
  320 S.C. 515, 466 S.E.2d 357 (1996).Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent
  conclusions from the evidence does not mean the agencyâ€™s conclusion is
  unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Ellis v. Spartan Mills, 276 S.C.
  216, 277 S.E.2d 590 (1981). 
â€œConversely,
  where the Commissionâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law, this courtâ€™s
  review is plenary.â€Â  Lizee v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 367
  S.C. 122, 126, 623 S.E.2d 860, 862 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An appellate court
  may reverse the Commission when its decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Callahan
    v. Beaufort County Sch. Dist., 375 S.C. 92, 651 S.E.2d
  311 (2007).
III.
On appeal, Butts contends the circuit court erred in
  ruling there was substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s findings (1)
  that Butts did not sustain a psychological injury or the aggravation of a
  pre-existing psychological problem as a result of his work-related accident,
  and (2) that Buttsâ€™ inability to sustain gainful employment was not due to any
  work-related injury.Â  He further asserts the combined effects of his
  pre-existing psychological condition and his subsequent injury resulted in a
  greater disability than he would have experienced from the injury alone,
  resulting in his inability to work and complete disability under the legal
  standard recently set forth in Ellison v. Frigidaire Home Products, 371
  S.C. 159, 638 S.E.2d 664 (2006).Â  He asserts the application of an
  inappropriate legal standard affected the Commissionâ€™s determination and thus
  constituted an error of law. 
In reversing the single commissionerâ€™s award, the Commission
  stated records from the Department of Veteran Affairs noted Butts had â€œreported
  symptoms of PTSD, including depression, loss of sleep, loss of interest in
  pleasurable things, loss of energy, loss of concentration, increased appetite
  and suicidal ideation, and that he â€˜has been getting progressively worse for
  roughly four years.â€™â€Â  The Commission observed this note was prepared two weeks
  after Buttsâ€™ injury and makes no reference to any physical injury he sustained
  while working for his employer.Â  
The Commission also
  noted Dr. E. Selman Watson, who evaluated Butts at the request of England
  Trucking, had found Buttsâ€™ emotional condition followed a slow and insidious
  course that had been building before the accident.Â  The Commission stated, â€œDr.
  Watson is further of the opinion that while the accident may have contributed
  to the Claimantâ€™s decline, other medical ailments suffered by the Claimant, and
  which pre-date the accident involved here, may have also served to threaten his
  livelihood.â€Â  Â Â 
The circuit court
  summarily noted â€œthere is strong evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding[]
  that [Buttsâ€™] pre[-]existing psychological condition was not aggravated by the
  injury to his lower back.â€Â  The circuit court stated there was evidence cited
  by the Commission that Butts suffered from psychological and physical problems
  prior to his accident and that he had applied for work since the date of his
  accident.Â  Â Â Â 
On appeal Butts cites Ellison, in which our
  supreme court held â€œ[t]here is no requirement that the pre-existing condition
  aggravated the injury, or that the injury aggravated the pre-existing
  condition, so long as there is a greater disability simply from the â€˜combined
  effectsâ€™ of the injury and the pre-existing condition.â€Â  371 S.C at 164, 638
  S.E.2d at 666.Â  In that case, Ellison fractured his leg, causing a twenty
  percent disability.Â  Id. at 161, 638 S.E.2d at 665.Â  The court held
  Ellisonâ€™s pre-existing physical conditions, including hypertension, sleep
  apnea, prostate cancer, diabetes, and congestive cardiac disease, were properly
  considered to determine that Ellison was entitled to permanent and total
  disability benefits because he was physically unable to work after his
  accident.Â  Id.Â  
Our
  supreme court further noted in Ellison that the proper section to apply
  was not the scheduled injury statute found at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30 (1985
  & Supp. 2006), but rather, the general disability statute, id. Â§
  42-9-400(a) (1985), which provides in pertinent part as follows:Â  

  If an employee who has a permanent physical impairment
    from any cause or origin incurs a subsequent disability from injury by accident
    arising out of and in the course of his employment, resulting in compensation
    and medical payments liability or either, for disability that is
      substantially greater, by reason of the combined effects of the preexisting
      impairment and subsequent injury or by reason of the aggravation of the
      preexisting impairment, than that which would have resulted from the subsequent
      injury alone, the employer or his insurance carrier shall in the first
    instance pay all awards of compensation and medical benefits provided by this
    Title; but such employer or his insurance carrier shall be reimbursed from the
    Second Injury Fund . . . .Â  (Emphasis added.)[2]

Relying
  upon Ellison, Butts contends the Commissionâ€™s â€œfinding that [he] did not
  suffer any psychological injury or aggravation of a pre[-]existing
  psychological problem as a result of [his work-related] accident . . . was not
  supported by the substantial evidence in the record.â€Â  He further contends
  that, â€œto the extent . . . the . . . findings are predicated upon a requirement
  that the pre[-]existing condition have been aggravated by the work-related
  accident, those findings are erroneous as a matter of law, in that they are not
  consistent with the [South Carolina] Supreme Court holding in Ellison v. Frigidaire
    Home Products.â€Â Â Â Â Â  
Butts
  further asserts that â€œ[t]he substantial evidence in
  the record supports a finding that [he] sustained a physical injury as a result
  of a work-related accident which, when combined with the pre[-]existing mental
  illness, rendered him incapable of continuing to work as a long distance truck
  driver, and therefore, rendered him permanently incapable of performing gainful
  employment.â€  England Trucking presents a different take on the
  evidence and argues application of the Ellison standard does not affect
  the result reached by the Commission because â€œ[t]he substantial evidence here
  shows that the injury to Mr. Buttsâ€™ lower back did not combine with, or
  aggravate, his PTSD [post-traumatic stress disorder] to cause any disability.Â 
  The Commission found that the evidence shows Mr. Buttsâ€™ inability to work, if
  any, is caused solely by that non-work related condition.â€Â  Â Â 
We do agree with Butts that the Commission erred in not following
  the Ellison standard.Â  We, however, decline to reach the ultimate merits
  of Buttsâ€™ position under the Ellison standard.Â  We believe in the first instance that the Commission should be given
  the opportunity to assess and weigh the evidence under the proper legal
  standard.Â  Â Â Â 
As
  noted above, the court in Ellison held it is not necessary that the new
  injury aggravate the pre-existing condition; rather, it is enough if the combined
    effects of the new injury and the pre-existing condition result in a
  greater disability to the claimant.Â  In the current appeal, neither the
  Commission nor the circuit court had the benefit of Ellison at the time
  their decisions were rendered and they did not apply this legal standard.[3]Â 
  Rather, they seemed to focus on the fact that Butts suffered from a
  pre-existing impairment that allegedly was not exacerbated by the subsequent
  accident, which is not the standard in Ellison. 
As a
  result, we reverse and remand this case to the circuit court, which shall send
  the case back to the Commission with instructions that the Commission consider,
  on the existing record, Buttsâ€™ claim under the Ellison standard.Â  
IV.
For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is 
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] Butts reportedly acquired this condition as a result
  of his service in Vietnam.Â  He first received treatment for this stress
  condition in September 2000.Â  
[2]Â  Section 42-9-400(a) was recently amended, but the change
  does not affect this appeal as it applies only to injuries occurring on or
  after July 1, 2007.Â  The amendment eliminated the language regarding the
  combined effects.Â  The statute now provides in relevant part:Â  â€œIf an employee
  who has a permanent physical impairment from any cause or origin incurs a
  subsequent disability from injury by accident arising out of and in the course
  of his employment, resulting in compensation and medical payments liability or
  either, for disability that is substantially greater and is caused by
    aggravation of the preexisting impairment than that which would have
  resulted from the subsequent injury alone, the employer or his insurance
  carrier shall pay all awards of compensation and medical benefits provided by
  this title . . . .â€ Â 2007 Act No. 111, Pt. II, Â§ 3 (emphasis added). Â We do not
  reach the question whether Ellison has been effectively overruled by
  2007 Act No. 111.Â  However, since the change applies only to injuries occurring
  on or after July 1, 2007, the current appeal must be decided under the version
  of section 42-9-400 that was applicable at the time of Buttsâ€™ injury, which is
  the same version of the statute that was applied in Ellison.
[3]Â  Ellison was issued on November 20, 2006; the
  Commissionâ€™s order was filed on March 15, 2005 and the circuit courtâ€™s
  order was filed on July 20, 2006.Â  Ellison does not represent new law,
  but is simply a matter of statutory interpretation.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        In the Matter
          of the Care and Treatment of Wayne Wooten, Respondent,
        v.
        The State of South Carolina, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-065
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
22, 2008

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, Assistant
          Attorney General R. Westmoreland Clarkson, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Appellate Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of the South Carolina
          Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The State filed a petition in the circuit court against
  Wayne Wooten under the South Carolina Sexually Violent Predator (SVP) Act, S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-10 to -170 (2002 & Supp. 2006), alleging Wooten met the
  statutory requirements for civil commitment as a SVP.Â  The circuit court denied
  the petition, and the State appeals, arguing the circuit court erred (1) in
  refusing to consider evidence of a prior offense that did not result in a
  conviction, and (2) in finding there was no probable cause to believe Wooten satisfies
  the definition of a SVP.Â  We reverse and remand.[1] 
1. On December 28,
  2005, the State filed a petition to declare Wooten a SVP and to seek his civil
  commitment.Â  At the probable cause hearing, the State presented evidence that
  Wooten was indicted in 2000 for assault with intent to commit criminal sexual
  conduct in the first degree with a ten-year old girl for an incident that
  occurred in 1999.Â  In addition, the State presented evidence that Wooten pled
  guilty in 2003[2] to a charge of committing a lewd act on a child from an incident arising in
  2001 and was sentenced to six years in prison.Â  The victim in that case was a
  nine-year-old girl.Â  
2.Â The circuit court
  found there was no probable cause to classify Wooten as a SVP. Â In its
  order, the circuit court found â€œthat in connection with the unconvicted charge
  of Assault with Intent to Commit Criminal Sexual Conduct with a Minor in the
  First Degree that the law presumes an individual is innocent until proven
  guilty.â€Â  The court â€œconclude[d] as a matter of law [that it could not]
  consider such unconvicted conduct.â€Â  The court further found â€œthat the
  remaining conviction of Lewd Act upon a Child is not sufficient to establish
  probable cause.â€Â  The State appeals. 
3. The circuit court erred as a
  matter of law in holding that the court, in evaluating a petition for probable
  cause under the SVP Act, could not consider evidence of Wootenâ€™s alleged and
  unadjudicated offense of assault with intent to commit first degree criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Section 44-48-50 of the SVP Act states the
  Director of the Department of Corrections â€œmust appoint a multidisciplinary
  team to review the records of each person referred to the teamâ€ and that
  â€œ[t]hese records may include, but are not limited to, the personâ€™s criminal
    offense record, any relevant medical and psychological records, treatment
  records, victimâ€™s impact statement, and any disciplinary or other records
  formulated during confinement or supervision.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-50
  (Supp. 2006) (emphasis added).Â  In the recent case of In re Care and
    Treatment of White, 375 S.C. 1, 649 S.E.2d 172 (Ct. App. 2007), this court
  observed that â€œoffenseâ€ is an ambiguous term because it is unclear whether
  â€œoffenseâ€ refers to a conviction or whether it refers to the commission of a
  crime.Â  Id. at 8, 649 S.E.2d at 176.Â  We noted the customary and usual
  meaning of â€œoffenseâ€ is that it refers to a violation of the law, as
  distinguished from a conviction, which is a judicial finding that someone is guilty
  of a crime.Â  Id.Â  We further noted, â€œ[W]hile a conviction cannot occur without
  the commission of an offense, an offense can occur without necessarily
  resulting in a conviction.â€Â  Id. at 9, 649 S.E.2d at 176.Â  We concluded
  that, â€œ[b]ecause the legislature fails to limit or is silent on whether
  offenses can include only convictions, we must assume the legislature intended
  to include both convictions and offenses not resulting in convictions.â€Â  Id.Â  Therefore, evidence of Wootenâ€™s alleged offense of assault with intent to
  commit first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor was relevant to the
  probable cause determination.
4. A SVP is defined under the SVP Act
  as â€œa person who . . . (a) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense;
  and (b) suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes
  the person likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a
  secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-48-30(1) (Supp. 2006).Â  At the hearing, the State offered evidence regarding
  Wootenâ€™s past offenses, including a prior conviction for lewd act on a minor
  and an unadjudicated offense of assault with intent to commit first degree
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  Wootenâ€™s conviction for committing a
  lewd act on a minor satisfies the first prong in the definition of a SVP.Â  See In re Care and Treatment of Beaver, 372 S.C. 272, 276-78, 642 S.E.2d 578,
  580-81 (2007) (holding sufficient probable cause was established to find a
  person convicted of committing a lewd act upon a minor met the definition of a
  SVP and that a lewd act was a qualifying offense under the Act). The totality
  of the evidence presented, including evidence of Wootenâ€™s unadjudicated conduct,
  satisfies the statutory probable cause threshold that Wooten suffers from a
  mental abnormality or personality disorder within the meaning of the SVP Act.Â 
  We conclude the State established probable cause under the SVP Act.
5. We reverse the circuit courtâ€™s
  finding of no probable cause, and we remand for further proceedings under the
  SVP Act as provided by law.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.
  

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  During the hearing, the Assistant Attorney General
  inadvertently referred to the date of conviction as being 1993, but the
  supporting documentation indicates the plea was in 2003, and this date is used
  by both parties in their appellate briefs.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Ex Parte:
        Protective Life
          Insurance Company, Respondent,
        v.
        Oakdale
          Investors, LP, Webb Properties, Inc., and J. Patton Webb, Appellants,
        ___________________
        In Re: 
        Marin
          Properties, LLC, Plaintiff,
        v.
        Oakdale
          Investors, LP, Central Bank of the South, Protective Life Insurance Company,
          and the State Street Bank and Trust Company, Defendants,
        and
        Protective Life
          Insurance Company and State Street Bank and Trust Company, Third-Party
          Plaintiffs, 
        v.
        Fletcher Bright
          Company, County of Spartanburg, Jean R. Jameson, in her official capacity as
          Delinquent Tax Collector for the County of Spartanburg, Webb Properties,
          Inc., HDC Corporation, J. Patton Webb, Thomas L. Hoofnagle, and ATFH Real
          Property, LLC, Third-Party
          Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Gordon G. Cooper, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-066
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January
22, 2008

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      J. Stephen Welch, of Greenwood, and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellants.
      J. Richard Kelly, of Greenville, for Respondent.
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this
  foreclosure action by a mortgage lender against a borrower and its general
  partners, Protective Life Insurance Company seeks to recover deficiency
  judgments against the borrowerâ€™s individual general partners under exceptions
  to the contractual nonrecourse provision.Â  We affirm as modified.[1]Â  
FACTS

Oakdale
  Investors, L.P. (Oakdale), is a South Carolina limited partnership whose
  general partners were Webb Properties, Inc. (Webb Properties); HDC Corporation;
  J. Patton Webb; and Thomas L. Hoofnagle (collectively Oakdale and its general
  partners).Â  On July 22, 1994, Oakdale executed a promissory note for
  $3,725,000.00 payable to Protective Life Insurance Company (Protective) and a
  mortgage and security agreement granting Protective a security interest in
  Oakdaleâ€™s real property known as the Oakdale Shopping Center (the Shopping
  Center).Â  Oakdale assigned Protective the Shopping Centerâ€™s rents and leases.Â  
The
  promissory note included a nonrecourse provision preserving Oakdale and its general
  partners from â€œpersonal liability for the payment of the principal, interest,
  prepayment fee or Premium, if any.â€Â  However, Oakdale and its individual general
  partners could incur personal liability for â€œLenderâ€™s damage, loss, liability,
  costs and expenses, plus interest,â€ in five circumstances.Â  Paragraph 4 of the
  promissory note enumerated those circumstances, including â€œ(a) failure by
  Borrower to perform the other obligations contained in the Loan Documents
  including, but not limited to, the obligations to . . . pay ad valorem taxes
  and assessmentsâ€ and â€œ(b) fraud or misrepresentation by Borrower (or any
  general partner) to Lender prior to or during the term of this Note.â€Â  
The
  Shopping Center property generated rental income sufficient to pay ordinary
  expenses, including property taxes.Â  Spartanburg County notified Oakdale of the
  2002 ad valorem taxes it levied on the Shopping Center.Â  Webb personally
  received this notice on behalf of Oakdale, but he failed to pay the taxes.Â  Spartanburg   County notified Oakdale the Shopping Center would be sold at a tax sale.Â  Webb
  personally received this notice as well but failed to notify Protective of the
  tax delinquency or the tax sale.Â  
Subsequently,
  Spartanburg County sold the Shopping Center to Marin Properties, LLC, and
  notified Oakdale it could redeem the property during a twelve-month redemption
  period.Â  Webb received this notice on behalf of Oakdale but failed to notify
  Protective of the redemption period.Â  Oakdale did not redeem the property
  within the redemption period.Â  
On
  March 29, 2005, Marin recorded a tax deed for the Shopping Center.Â  Marinâ€™s bid
  exceeded the tax debt on the property by $883,729.50 (the Overbid Funds).Â  Webb
  applied to Spartanburg County for the Overbid Funds and deposited them in
  Oakdaleâ€™s checking account.Â  Later, Webb personally attempted to repurchase the
  Shopping Center directly from Marin, using personal rather than partnership
  funds.Â  Although Marin sent Webb a contract naming Webb Properties and not
  Oakdale as the purchaser, Webb never executed the contract because he believed
  Marinâ€™s price was too high and he was uncomfortable with the contract itself.Â  
Marin
  deeded the Shopping Center to ATFH Real Property, LLC (ATFH).Â  One month later,
  Marin filed an action to quiet title to the Shopping Center.Â  Protective
  responded and asserted its claims under the promissory note.Â  The circuit court
  referred Marinâ€™s suit to the master for hearing and adjudication.Â  In response
  to a motion by Protective, the master appointed a receiver for the property.Â  The
  receiver took control of the Overbid Funds as well as the Shopping Centerâ€™s
  income.Â  Due to Oakdaleâ€™s failure to make scheduled payments, Protective
  invoked the promissory noteâ€™s acceleration provision against Oakdale.Â  
The
  master set aside the tax sale due to defective notice.Â  Under a negotiated
  agreement, the receiver disbursed the Overbid Funds to ATFH, and Marin and ATFH
  executed quitclaim deeds to Oakdale.Â  With the tax sale issue resolved, the
  master dismissed from the suit all parties except Protective, Oakdale, and
  Oakdaleâ€™s general partners.Â  
On
  September 15, 2006, the master entered judgment on the foreclosure action to
  Protective and awarded Protective $3,727,460.98, plus interest, from Oakdale.Â  The
  master ordered the property sold at auction, with the proceeds to be applied to
  Oakdaleâ€™s entire debt.Â  The master found Oakdaleâ€™s failure to pay ad valorem
  taxes on the property triggered an exception to the promissory noteâ€™s
  nonrecourse provision.Â  Further, the master found $346,648.27 (the Tax Issue
  Loss) of the grand total was attributable to Protectiveâ€™s efforts to resolve
  the issues stemming from Oakdaleâ€™s failure to pay taxes timely.Â  As a result,
  the master found joint and several liability among Oakdale and all its general
  partners in an amount up to $346,648.27 for Protectiveâ€™s losses as a result of
  Oakdaleâ€™s nonpayment of property taxes.Â  The master ruled Protective was
  entitled to a deficiency judgment against the individual partners, jointly and
  severally, for any portion of the Tax Issue Loss that remained unpaid after
  sale of the property.Â  Moreover, the master found Webbâ€™s pursuit of the overbid
  funds and a contract of sale with ATFH constituted fraud. Â As a result of the
  fraud, the master found Protective entitled to a deficiency judgment against
  Oakdale and each of its partners, jointly and severally, for both the Tax Issue
  Losses and all sums owed under the terms of the note that remained unpaid after
  sale of the property.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Actions
  for foreclosure are actions in equity.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 324 S.C.
  570, 576-77, 479 S.E.2d 510, 513 (1996).Â  In an
    appeal from the final judgment of a master, the reviewing court applies the
    same scope of review as if the appeal were from the circuit court without a
    jury to the Supreme Court.Â  See Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc.,
    301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990) (â€œOur scope of review for a
    case heard by a Master-in-Equity who enters a final judgment is the same as
    that for review of a case heard by a circuit court without a jury.â€); Wigfall
      v. Fobbs, 295 S.C. 59, 60-61, 367 S.E.2d 156, 157 (1988) (applying the
    standard of review from a law case heard by the circuit court to a law case
    heard by the master).Â  In an action in equity, tried by a master without a
  jury, an appellate court may view the evidence to determine facts in accordance
  with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Tiger, 301 S.C.
  at 237, 391 S.E.2d at 543.
LAW/ANALYSIS

Oakdale,
  Webb Properties, and Webb argue that the master erred in finding joint and
  several liability on the basis of fraud.Â  We disagree.Â  
I. Fraud 
As a
  preliminary matter, we find that our review of this issue is governed by the
  equitable standard enunciated above rather than by a legal standard triggered
  by fraud.Â  We recognize that, when legal and equitable actions are maintained in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal
  or equitable for purposes of the applicable standard of
  review on appeal.Â  Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 89, 92, 485 S.E.2d 97,
  99 (1997).[2]Â 
  In determining whether a cause of action is at law or in equity:

  [T]he
    appellate court must look to the essential character of the cause of action
    alleged by the petitioners in the court below.Â  If the essential character of
    the petitionerâ€™s cause of action is grounded on equitable rights and equitable
    relief is sought, the case is regarded as equitable and the appellate court has
    jurisdiction to make findings in accordance with its own view of the
    preponderance of the evidence.Â  

Dean v. Kilgore, 313 S.C. 257, 259, 437 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App.
  1993).Â  However, in the case at bar, the fraud asserted is not an action at
  law.Â  Protective asserted fraud by Oakdale and its general partners, not as a
  separate cause of action arising out of a common event, but as a means of
  invoking one of the contractual exceptions to the promissory noteâ€™s nonrecourse
  provision.Â  The essential nature of this action is equitable. Â The assertion of
  fraud here is inextricably part of the equitable claim for foreclosure.Â 
  Therefore, we will determine facts in accordance with our view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Tiger, 301 S.C. at 237, 391 S.E.2d at
  543.Â  Having decided the action is one in equity, we now turn to examine
  whether the master erred in concluding Oakdale committed fraud.Â  
Oakdale
  and its general partners had a fiduciary duty to disclose to Protective any
  known threats to Protectiveâ€™s interest in the Shopping Center.Â  In South Carolina, a party to a transaction may assume a duty to disclose in three ways:Â  

  First,
    where it arises from a pre-existing definite fiduciary relation between the
    parties; second where one party expressly reposes a trust and confidence in the
    other with reference to the particular transaction in question, or else from
    the circumstances of the case, the nature of their dealings, or their position
    towards each other, such a trust and confidence in the particular case is
    necessarily implied.Â  The third class includes those instances where the very
    contract or transaction itself, in its essential nature, is intrinsically
    fiduciary, and necessarily calls for perfect good faith and full disclosure,
    without regard to any particular intention of the parties.Â  

Holly Hill Lumber Co.,
  Inc. v. McCoy, 201 S.C. 427, 437, 23
  S.E.2d 372, 376 (1942).Â  The party acting as a fiduciary must have either
  induced or actually accepted the other partyâ€™s trust.Â  Moore v. Moore,
  360 S.C. 241, 251, 599 S.E.2d 467, 472 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Regions Bank
    v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 671, 582 S.E.2d 432, 444 (Ct. App. 2003)).Â  A mortgagor
  in possession of mortgaged property occupies a fiduciary relation to the
  property and is required to act in a manner that will not impair the rights of his
  mortgagee.Â  Hill v. Winnsboro Granite Corp., 112 S.C. 243, 248, 99 S.E.
  836, 838 (1919).Â  
Here,
  Oakdale, through its general partners, executed a mortgage, promissory note,
  and security agreement granting Protective an interest in the Shopping Center,
  as well as an assignment of rents and leases.Â  By executing these documents and
  retaining possession of the Shopping Center, Oakdale and its general partners
  manifested their acceptance of Protectiveâ€™s trust and, consequently, acceptance
  of their fiduciary obligations to Protective.Â  Oakdale and its general partners
  signified they promised not to impair Protectiveâ€™s rights to the Shopping
  Center and assumed the duty to disclose to Protective any threats to its
  interest in the property. Â 
Additionally,
  Oakdale fraudulently concealed from Protective known threats to Protectiveâ€™s
  interest in the property.Â  When a party to a transaction â€œconceals some fact
  which is material, which is within his own knowledge, and which it is his duty
  to disclose, he is guilty of actual fraud.â€Â  Holly Hill Lumber, 201 S.C.
  at 436, 23 S.E.2d at 376.Â  Webb admitted he personally knew about Oakdaleâ€™s
  failure to pay ad valorem taxes on the property, the tax sale of the property, and
  the redemption period that followed the tax sale.Â  Webb further admitted he did
  not notify Protective or its agent of any of these matters.Â  Oakdale and its
  general partners had a duty to disclose to Protective threats against its interest
  in the Shopping Center.Â  Because Webb knew about these threats, Webbâ€™s failure
  disclose them to Protective constitutes fraud.Â  We therefore find Oakdale
  committed actual fraud against Protective, triggering Paragraph 4(b) of the promissory
  note.Â  
However,
  we disagree with the masterâ€™s award of â€œa deficiency judgment for fraud both in
  the amount of the Tax Issue Losses and in the amount of all other sums owed
  Protective under the terms of the Note.â€Â  Paragraph 4(b), upon which liability
  here is premised, does not obviate the nonrecourse provision entirely.Â  Rather,
  it provides a limited exception to the rule against personal liability.Â  The
  limited exception encompasses â€œLenderâ€™s damage, loss, liability, costs and
  expenses,â€ along with interest.Â  It does not expose Oakdaleâ€™s partners to
  personal liability for the â€œprincipal, interest, prepayment fee or Premium, if
  any,â€ under the note.Â  Therefore, we find Oakdale and its general partners have
  joint and several personal liability for the costs Protective incurred to
  protect its rights, plus interest, but not for the principal amounts due under
  the note.Â  
II.Â Additional
  Sustaining Grounds
Protective
  urges us to affirm the masterâ€™s judgment on additional sustaining grounds.[3]Â 
  We affirm the masterâ€™s judgment of joint and several liability based upon Oakdaleâ€™s
  failure to pay ad valorem taxes on the property.Â  Paragraph 4(a) of the note
  extends joint and several liability to Oakdaleâ€™s general partners for â€œfailure
  . . . to . . . pay ad valorem taxes and assessments with respect to the
  Property.â€Â  Personal liability under Paragraph 4(a) is the same limited
  liability as under Paragraph 4(b).Â  Webb admitted to failing to pay these
  taxes, and the master found personal, joint and several liability for the Tax
  Issue Loss on this basis.Â  Therefore, under Paragraph 4(a) of the note, Oakdale
  and its general partners incurred joint and several personal liability for the
  Tax Issue Loss, plus interest, by failing to pay ad valorem taxes on the
  Shopping Center.Â  
CONCLUSION
The
  master did not err in finding Oakdale and its general partners personally
  liable, both jointly and severally, to Protective under exceptions to the
  nonrecourse provision in the note.Â  However, their personal liability extends
  only to the amount of the Tax Issue Loss, plus interest.Â  A preponderance of
  the evidence supports the masterâ€™s findings that Oakdale had a fiduciary duty
  to notify Protective of known threats to Protectiveâ€™s interest in the Shopping
  Center, Oakdale knew the Spartanburg County Tax Collector intended to sell the
  property at a tax sale, and Oakdale fraudulently failed or refused to inform
  Protective its interest in the property was in jeopardy.Â  Additionally, we find
  Oakdale and its general partners incurred joint and several personal liability
  under the note for Protectiveâ€™s Tax Issue Loss, plus interest, by failing to
  pay ad valorem taxes levied on the property.Â  Accordingly, the order of the
  master is 
AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED.
HUFF
  AND PIEPER, JJ., AND CURETON, AJ., CONCUR.



[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

[2] Where legal and equitable actions co-exist in the
  same suit, the proper analysis is to view the actions separately for the
  purpose of determining the appropriate standard of review.Â  Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005).Â  An action for
  fraud is an action at law, and a legal question in an equity case receives
  review as in law.Â  Gunter v. Fallaw, 78 S.C. 457, 59 S.E. 70 (1907). Â An
  appellate courtâ€™s scope of review in cases of fraud, where the proof must be by
  clear, cogent and convincing evidence, is limited to determining whether there
  is any evidence reasonably supporting the circuit courtâ€™s findings.Â  Kiriakides
    v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc., 343 S.C. 587, 594, 541 S.E.2d 257,
  261 (2001).
[3] â€œUnder the present rules, a respondent - the â€˜winnerâ€™
  in the lower court - may raise on appeal any additional reasons the appellate
  court should affirm the lower courtâ€™s ruling, regardless of whether those
  reasons have been presented to or ruled on by the lower court.â€Â  Iâ€™On,
    L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723
  (2000).Â  Similarly, a respondentâ€™s failure to raise an additional sustaining
  ground in its appellate brief constitutes abandonment of that ground.Â  Id.Â  However, the basis for a respondentâ€™s additional sustaining grounds must appear
  in the record on appeal.Â  Id.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Curtis Scott, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Jasper County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-067
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January
  23, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Harold M. Coombs,
  Jr., Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia;
  and Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Curtis Scott was convicted of
  attempted armed robbery and sentenced to thirteen years in prison.Â  He appeals,
  arguing the trial court erred in admitting the in-court identifications of him
  because they were based upon an unduly suggestive pretrial identification
  procedure and were not otherwise reliable.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  Â 
I.
Scott was charged with attempting to rob Miguel Leyva
  of his wallet in the parking lot of a Food Lion in Ridgeland, South Carolina.Â 
  Both Leyva and Shawnricka Burrison, a store employee who observed the incident,
  picked Scott out of a photographic lineup shortly after the incident, and they
  again identified Scott at trial as the perpetrator.Â   
Prior
  to trial, Scott made a motion to exclude the identifications of the two
  eyewitnesses.Â  During the in limine hearing on the motion, Leyva, who speaks
  little English, testified through an interpreter that a man approached him in
  the parking lot and asked him for a cigarette, and he told the man he didnâ€™t
  smoke.Â  The man then got inside Leyvaâ€™s car, pulled a gun on him, and asked for
  his wallet.Â  Leyva opened the car door, hit the man with his arm, and then ran
  towards the Food Lion while calling 9-1-1 on his cell phone.Â  Burrison
  testified that she had walked outside the store on her break when she observed
  the conflict between Leyva and the other man.Â  She stated the perpetrator was
  wearing a red jersey shirt and blue jeans and appeared to be harassing the victim.Â 
  Burrison stated once the victim appeared to be attracting attention, the
  perpetrator shoved something into the waistband of his pants and then ran
  behind the store.Â  Burrison advised her store manager about the problem and the
  manager called the police.Â  Burrison stated she had seen the perpetrator before
  because he had come into the store on prior occasions, but she did not know his
  name.Â   
The police prepared
  two photo lineups.Â  The first lineup, prepared shortly after the incident,
  consisted of photos of people the police thought were likely to have committed
  the crime.Â  Scottâ€™s photo was not included in the first lineup.Â  A few days
  later, after receiving several tips, the police presented seven photos in a
  stack to Leyva and Burrison and each positively identified Scott as the
  perpetrator.Â  The officer who presented the photos, Michael Ballenski,
  testified that he did not suggest anything to the witnesses when they viewed
  the photos and simply handed them the stack of photos and asked if the person
  who had attempted the robbery was in any of the photos.Â  He stated Burrison
  â€œimmediatelyâ€ identified Scott as the person she saw at the store.Â  Burrison
  signed the back of the photo to indicate she had identified Scott.Â  The officer
  stated Leyva was then shown the photos.Â  Burrison was not present.Â  Once Leyva
  identified Scott as the person who had attempted to rob him, the photo was then
  turned over for Leyva to sign.Â  The officer explained that the witnesses were
  not together when the identifications were made, and Leyva could not see
  Burrisonâ€™s identification before he made his own identification of Scott.Â 
 
At the in limine
  hearing, Burrison testified that she was handed a stack of photos and they were
  not in any particular order.Â  Burrison stated she looked at all of them and
  recognized Scott as the robber.Â  Burrison stated the officer stood back while
  she looked at the photos so she could not ask him any questions.Â  Burrison
  stated there was nothing about any of the photographs that focused particular
  attention on any of them and that she â€œreviewed them all the same.â€Â  She stated
  her identification was based on what she had seen during the incident.Â  Â Â 
Leyva testified
  through an interpreter and stated when he saw the second set of photos the
  officer stated only, â€œIâ€™m bringing you a couple of more pictures to see if you
  can identify the person that did whatever happened.â€Â  When asked if there was
  anything said or done to make one photo any more or less special, Leyva stated
  â€œ[t]hey were all normal pictures.â€Â  Leyva said he recognized Scott in the
  second set of photographs and after he identified Scott, the officer then told
  him he needed to sign the back of the photo.Â  Leyva stated he did not see the
  back of the photo prior to turning it over to sign it.Â   
The trial judge,
  while noting the police could have done some things better, found â€œas a fact
  that under . . . all the circumstances of this case . . . this identification
  by both witnesses was reliableâ€ and ruled that their testimony as to identity
  would be admissible at trial.Â  Scott was subsequently convicted as charged.
II.
On appeal, Scott contends the trial judge erred in
  admitting the in-court identifications of him because they were based upon an
  unduly suggestive pretrial identification procedure and the identifications
  were not otherwise reliable under Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972).
â€œThe
  United States Supreme Court has developed a two-prong inquiry [in Neil v.
    Biggers] to determine the admissibility of an out-of-court identification.â€Â  State v. Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 503, 589 S.E.2d 781, 784 (Ct.
  App. 2003).Â  â€œFirst, a court must ascertain whether the identification process
  was unduly suggestive.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe court must next decide whether the
  out-of-court identification was nevertheless so reliable that no substantial
  likelihood of misidentification existed.â€Â  Id.
Â â€œEven assuming an identification procedure is suggestive, it need not be excluded so long as, under all the
  circumstances, the identification was reliable notwithstanding the suggestiveness.â€Â  State v. Traylor, 360
  S.C. 74, 82, 600 S.E.2d 523, 527 (2004).Â  â€œThe inquiry must focus upon
  whether, under the totality of the circumstances, there was a substantial
  likelihood of irreparable misidentification.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe following
  factors should be considered in evaluating the totality of the circumstances to
  determine the likelihood of a misidentification:Â  (1) the witnessâ€™s opportunity
  to view the perpetrator at the time of the crime, (2) the witnessâ€™s degree of
  attention, (3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior description of the
  perpetrator, (4) the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the
  confrontation, and (5) the length of time between the crime and the
  confrontation.â€Â  Id.
â€œGenerally,
  the decision to admit an eyewitness identification is in the trial judgeâ€™s
  discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion,
  or the commission of prejudicial legal error.â€Â  Brown, 356 S.C. at
  502, 589 S.E.2d at 784.
Scott argues the
  photos were unduly suggestive because Scott â€œwas the only person in the photos
  wearing a white undershirt, was the only one who[se] photo was vertically
  oriented, was the only one in front of a bulletin board that read â€œSecure at
  all time,â€ was in the only photo without a computer-generated name printed on
  his photo, and was depicted in the largest photograph.Â  Scott also contends the
  paper is lightweight so Burrisonâ€™s signature could â€œeasily be seen by Leyva,
  influencing his choice.â€Â  Finally, Scott contends Burrison knew of two of the
  people in the photo lineup and that three of them shared her same last name.Â  Â Â 
After reviewing the
  photo lineup, it appears the trial judge properly exercised his discretion in
  ruling the identifications were admissible.Â  Scottâ€™s arguments, while numerous,
  are ultimately without merit.Â  The photos are all on plain paper that is 8Â½ by
  11 inches, one sheet for each suspect, and each sheet has two photos of that
  suspect, a front view and a side view.Â  Although Scottâ€™s photos are oriented in
  a different direction on the page from the majority, another suspectâ€™s photos
  also are oriented differently from the others and there is a double border
  around the photos, so there is nothing remarkable about Scottâ€™s photos.Â  As
  noted by both witnesses, Scottâ€™s photos appear to be normal and nothing makes
  his stand out from the others.Â   
Further,
  contrary to Scottâ€™s argument, his photo is not larger than all of the others.Â 
  Rather, it is the same size as at least one other suspect, and there is not
  much difference between the sizes, in any event.Â  Moreover, his is not the only
  photo that does not have a name on it.Â  Scott is wearing a white undershirt,
  that is true, but all of the other individuals except one are wearing a white
  undershirt with another T-shirt over it.Â  In fact, one individual is wearing a
  red T-shirt, the same color as the perpetrator.Â  The bulletin board Scott
  refers to is so blurry as to be unreadable, and the wording he references is,
  for the most part, obscured behind Scottâ€™s head and does not actually appear in
  full on the photo as he alleges.Â  As to the signatures, the only evidence in
  the record is that Leyva was not present when Burrison made her identification
  and he did not see Burrisonâ€™s identification before making his own identification
  of Scott.Â   
The
  only arguable issue with the lineup appears to be the fact that people with the
  same last name as one of the witnesses appeared in the lineup.Â  There are
  photos of a Marcus Burrison, a Nathaniel Burrison, and a Gil Nathaniel Burrison.Â 
  Burrison stated she was not related to Marcus Burrison and she knew of the
  others.Â  (It is unclear from the record whether the last two might even be the
  same person as the names and photos are similar and Scott notes in his brief
  that Nathaniel Burrison and Gil Nathaniel Burrison appear to be the same
  person.)Â  However, while the lineup could arguably be deemed suggestive, we
  hold it is not unduly suggestive, which is the applicable standard.Â  See State v. Turner, 373 S.C. 121, 644 S.E.2d 693 (2007) (stating the fact
  that a suspectâ€™s photo is in color and the others are in black and white or that
  the suspectâ€™s photo is larger or in a different position on the page is not
  unduly suggestive; the court noted the trial judgeâ€™s observation that there
  will always be differences found in photos); State v. Govan, 372
  S.C. 552, 643 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2007) (stating although the showup
  identification procedure in that case was suggestive, it was not unduly
  suggestive under the test articulated in Neil v. Biggers).  
Moreover,
  even assuming the photos are unduly suggestive, however, the inquiry then
  focuses on whether, under the totality of the circumstances, they were
  nevertheless reliable.Â  It is evident from the testimony of the witnesses that
  they each had ample opportunity to view Scott, Burrison had even seen him at
  the store before, and they were uniformly certain in their identifications.Â 
  The incident occurred at close range in broad daylight, and both Leyva and
  Burrison were focused on the acts of the perpetrator.Â  The officer stated
  Burrison â€œimmediatelyâ€ identified Scott after viewing the photos, and there is
  no evidence that Leyva was influenced in his selection of Scott.Â  As noted by
  the trial judge, the officers certainly could have done some things differently
  in preparing the photo lineup, but in looking at the totality of the
  circumstances there is not a very substantial likelihood of misidentification
  in this case.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in
  admitting the identifications of Scott.
III.
Scottâ€™s conviction and sentence are,
  therefore,
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				John Daniel
      Springer, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Darlington County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-069
Heard January 8, 2008 â€“ Filed January 23,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
  Jay Hodge, Fourth Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Cheraw, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: John Daniel Springer (Springer) appeals his conviction
  and sentence for two counts each of first-degree criminal sexual assault with a
  minor, committing a lewd act on a minor, and contributing to the delinquency of
  a minor.Â  Springer alleges the trial court erred in improperly joining and
  refusing to sever cases involving separate alleged incidents and different
  victims.Â  We affirm.Â   
FACTS
In
  February 2002, Officer Dennis Carter took an incident report identifying
  alleged sexual assaults by Springer on his daughter (Jane Doe) and niece (Jane
  Roe).[1]Â 
  Based on the evidence gathered through the subsequent investigation, Springer
  was arrested and charged with various criminal acts against the victims. 
 
Prior
  to trial, Springer filed a motion to sever the trials involving the alleged
  crimes against the victims.Â  At a pre-trial hearing, Springer argued the cases
  did not contain sufficient similarities to warrant consolidation.Â  The trial
  court denied Springerâ€™s motion to sever.Â  The trial court found the cases
  involving the victims were â€œvery similar,â€ including similarities in the
  nature, location, and execution of the alleged acts.Â  In addition, the trial court
  acknowledged each victim would be a witness in the otherâ€™s case.Â  Based on this
  reasoning, the trial court held the cases should be consolidated.Â   
For
  acts committed against Jane Doe and Jane Roe, the jury found Springer guilty of
  two counts each of first-degree criminal sexual assault with a minor,
  committing a lewd act on a minor, and contributing to the delinquency of a
  minor.Â  The trial court sentenced Springer to thirty years imprisonment for
  each of the charges of first degree criminal sexual assault with a minor,
  fifteen years for each of the charges of committing a lewd act on a minor, and
  three years for each of the charges of contributing to the delinquency of a
  minor, all to run concurrently.Â   
Pursuant
  to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), counsel for Springer
  attached to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating she
  reviewed the record and concluded the appeal was without legal merit sufficient
  to warrant a new trial.Â  After a thorough review of the record, we ordered the
  parties to brief whether the circuit court improperly consolidated the
  charges.Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  trial court has broad discretion when determining whether to consolidate
  charges for trial.Â  State v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 23, 564 S.E.2d 331, 333
  (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision will be reversed if an abuse of
  discretion has occurred.Â  Id.Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  trial judge has the power, in his discretion, to order offenses charged in
  separate indictments to be tried together when the offenses are of the same
  general nature involving connected transactions closely related in kind, place,
  and character, and the defendantâ€™s substantive rights would not be prejudiced.Â  State
    v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 350, 573 S.E.2d 856, 860 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
 
â€œOffenses
  are considered to be of the same general nature where they are
  interconnected.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œConversely, offenses which are of the same
  nature, but which do not arise out of a single chain of circumstances and are
  not provable by the same evidence may not properly be tried together.â€Â  State v. Jones,
  325 S.C. 310, 315, 479 S.E.2d 517, 519 (Ct. App. 1996).Â   
Accordingly,
  the Supreme Court of South Carolina has held, â€œCharges can be joined in the
  same indictment and tried together where they (1) arise out of a single chain
  of circumstances, (2) are proved by the same evidence, (3) are of the same
  general nature, and (4) no real right of the defendant has been prejudiced.â€Â  State
    v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 652, 572 S.E.2d 267, 272 (2002).Â  The court may
  consolidate trials involving multiple defendants, multiple victims, or both.Â  See Jones, 325 S.C. at 313-16, 479 S.E.2d at 518-20 (holding consolidation
  of cases against two adults involving the sexual abuse of two minor victims was
  proper).Â   
In
  the present case, the charges arise out of a single chain of circumstances.Â  Jane
  Doe and Jane Roe, both young females, were assaulted in Springerâ€™s home.Â  The
  young victims were assaulted at night.Â  The girls were assaulted at times when
  others were present in the house. The victims are related to Springer.Â  Additionally,
  the acts committed against the victims were of the same general nature,
  including vaginal fondling and performing cunnilingus.Â   
The charges
  are proved by the same evidence.Â  For example, Jane Doe and Jane Roe would
  argue about which side of the bed each would sleep.Â  The bed in which the
  victims slept was a bunk bed.Â  The bed was positioned such that it was placed against
  the wall of the bedroom.Â  Consequently, one side of the bed was up against the
  wall, while the other side was open to the bedroom.Â  The victims would sleep
  together in the bottom part of the bunk bed.Â  Jane Roe testified that she and
  Jane Doe would argue as to which one would sleep on the side of the bed facing
  the wall.Â  The desire of each victim to sleep on the inside of the bed was fueled
  by their wish to escape the possibility of sexual abuse during the night by
  Springer.  
Moreover,
  Jane Doe testified to an occurrence during which Springer entered the bedroom and
  sexually abused Jane Roe.Â  Jane Doe testified that during the night, Springer entered
  the bedroom when the victims were asleep.Â  Jane Doe stated, â€œI thought it was
  just a dream but it wasnâ€™t because in the morning, I woke up and [Jane Roe] was
  acting all weird.â€Â  Jane Roe, in describing this occasion, testified that
  â€œ[Springer] came in and I was [a]sleep on the outside [of the bed] because
  [Jane Doe] was sleeping on the inside.Â  [Springer] just touched my private.â€Â 
  When asked whether she informed anyone, Jane Roe responded, â€œI remember I told
  [Jane Doe], but she told me it happened to her, but she never said what
  happened to her.â€Â  The foregoing demonstrates that Jane Doe and Jane Roe were
  necessary witnesses to corroborate the circumstances of sexual abuse that
  occurred to each other.Â   
The
  final factor to consider in determining whether consolidation is warranted is
  if any real right of the defendant has been prejudiced.Â  Springer argues consolidation
  prevented him from calling his wife (Wife) as a material witness for charges
  relating to Jane Roe.Â  Wife was charged with unlawful neglect involving Jane
  Doe.Â  During trial, Wife was called as a witness.Â  However, Wife refused to
  testify on the grounds of her Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.Â  Springer
  contends consolidation prevented him from calling Wife as a witness for charges
  involving Jane Roe because Wife was charged with unlawful neglect involving
  only Jane Doe.Â   
Even
  if Springer was tried separately, and Wife testified as a witness for charges
  relating to Jane Roe, there is sufficient evidence to conclude the trial judge
  did not abuse his discretion in consolidating the charges.Â  In addition to Jane
  Doeâ€™s and Jane Roeâ€™s testimony described above, Jane Roe gave additional testimony
  which described in graphic detail Springerâ€™s acts.

	Q: Was there ever a time when something
  happened that made you feel uncomfortable?
	A: Yes, maâ€™am.
	Q: Can you tell us what you remember about
  that?
	A: Yes, maâ€™am.Â  [Springer] would touch and
  lick my private.
	. . . 
	Q: And has that happened one time or more
  than one time?
	A: More than once.
	. . . 
	Q: I want to ask you about one of the
  first times you remember something happening, and can you kind of just describe
  where you were when it first started?
	A: I donâ€™t remember where, but I remember
  what happened. 
	Q: Okay. Can you tell us about that? 
	A: [Springer] would just touch my private.
	Q: About how old were you when this first
  started to happen?
	A: Eight or nine.
	. . . 
	Q: Would these things normally happen in
  the daytime or nighttime? 
	A: Nighttime.
	Q: What do you remember about that?
	A: Iâ€™d be sleep, [sic] and [Springer
  would] just wake me up.
	Q: How would you wake up?
	A: With him touching me. 
	Q: And would that be on top or underneath
  your clothes? 
	A: Underneath.
	Q: Can you tell us what part or parts of
  your body?
	A: My private. 
	. . . 
	Q: And did he touch your private part one
  time or more than one time? 
	A: More than one time. 
	Q: Okay. I need to ask you if you can
  describe what kind of touching that was. 
	A: He just rubbed my private.
	Q: Okay. Can you tell us what you mean by
  rubbing on your private. What part of your private? 
	A: It was the outside. 
	Q: Okay.Â  You said before that something
  else had happened to your private? 
	A: Yes, maâ€™am.
	Q: Okay. Can you tell us what that was? 
	A: He would lick inside my private. 

Â Additionally,
  our decision to affirm the trial court is supported by case law.Â  In Jones,
  two appellants were indicted on numerous charges arising out of their sexual
  abuse of two minors.Â  Id. at 313-14, 479 S.E.2d at 518-19.Â  The abuse of
  the minors occurred in December 1991, January 1992, and September 1992.Â  Id.Â  The trial court consolidated the charges against each appellant into one of two
  indictments, and they were tried jointly on each charge.Â  Id.Â  Consequently,
  the appellants were each convicted of three counts of first-degree criminal
  sexual conduct, two counts of second-degree criminal sexual conduct, five
  counts of criminal conspiracy, and one count of contributing to the delinquency
  of a minor.Â  Id.
On
  appeal, one of the issues presented was whether the trial court improperly
  consolidated the case.Â  Id. at 314-15, 479 S.E.2d at 519-20.Â  This Court,
  in affirming the trial court, held the charged offenses were of the same
  general nature involving allegations of a pattern of sexual abuse involving the
  two minor victims.Â  Id.Â  We also noted the evidence presented showed
  both victims had been taken to the same locations and were present in the same
  motel room on an occasion of abuse.Â  Id.Â   
As
  explained above, the record indicates similarities exist in the assaults
  against the victims.Â  Jane Doe and Jane Roe were assaulted in Springerâ€™s home.Â 
  Both were assaulted in the nighttime. Both were assaulted at times when others
  were present in the house, and some of the acts committed against the victims
  were similar in nature, including vaginal fondling and performing cunnilingus.Â  See State
    v. Grace, 350 S.C. 19, 24, 564 S.E.2d 331, 333 (Ct. App. 2002)
  (affirming consolidation when crimes were â€œinterconnected,â€ â€œ[a]ll incidents concerned the same parties,â€ incidents â€œtook
  place in the same location,â€ incidents occurred â€œwithin a relatively short time
  period,â€ and the evidence showed â€œa pattern of sexual abuse and was essentially the
  same for all chargesâ€).Â  Based on the foregoing, we conclude the trial court
  did not abuse its discretion in consolidating the charges.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF,
  WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] The actual names of the victims have been changed.Â
