THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Burriss
      Electrical, Inc., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Office of
      Occupational Safety and Health, South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing
      and Regulation, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-070
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January
  23, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Charles F. Thompson, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Joseph N. Connell, of Lugoff, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Burriss
  Electrical, Inc. (Burriss) appeals from a South Carolina Occupational Safety
  and Health Review Board (the Review Board) decision finding Burriss in willful
  violation of the South Carolina Occupational Safety and Health Regulation 71, 1-1926.651(k)(1)(1991)[1].Â  After two employees were killed
  when a vertical wall of an earthen trench collapsed, the Office of Occupational
  Safety and Health in the South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing and
  Regulation (the Department) cited Burriss for four serious violations and one
  willful violation of the South Carolina Occupational Safety and Health
  Regulation (the Act).Â  Burriss appeals the citation for the willful violation,
  arguing that (1) the Review Board misapplied the legal standard for willful conduct
  in reaching a finding of willfulness; and (2) under an appropriate application
  of the standard there exists no substantial evidence to support a finding
  Burriss committed a willful violation.Â  We affirm.[2]Â   
FACTS
Burriss is an electrical systems
  contractor.[3] Â During 2002 and 2003, Burriss served as the electrical contractor for the
  building of the Blythewood High School in Blythewood, South Carolina.Â  At the Blythewood
  site, Burriss dug a trench approximately 121 feet long in order to install
  feeder conduit for power and data communications underneath the building. Â Roughly
  eighty feet of the trench measured from six to eight feet deep, making that
  portion of the trench wall essentially vertical. Â Â 
On the
  morning of January 28, 2003, a portion of the trench wall collapsed on several Burriss employees working in the trench.Â  The cave-in partially buried two of
  the employees and caused their deaths.Â  The Department sent an inspector to
  conduct a fatality inspection of Burrissâ€™ Blythewood site.Â  As a result of the
  inspection, Burriss was cited for four serious violations (Citation 3 parts 1,
  2, 3, and 4) and one willful violation (Citation 4).[4]Â  The violations are as follows:  

	Citation 3 (Serious) 
	1. SCCR 71, 1-1926.21(b)(2) - Failure to instruct each
  employee in the recognition and avoidance of unsafe conditions. . . no trench
  hazard recognition [or] avoidance safety training provided to employees in
  trench in excess of 7 feet deep . . . 
	2. SCCR 71, 1-1926.100(a) - Failure to require employees
  working in areas where there is a possibility of head injury . . . to be protected
  by helmets [in that] . . . no protective helmets [were] worn by 4 employees in [a]
  trench in excess of 7 feet deep . . .
	3. SCCR 71, 1-1926.651(c)(2) - Failed to locate a stairway,
  ladder, ramp or other safe means of egress in trench excavation that are 4 feet
  or more in depth . . . 
	4. SCCR 71, 1-1926.652(a)(1) - Failed to protect each
  employee in an excavation from cave-in by an adequate protection system [and] 
	SCCR
    71, 1-1926.652(b)(1)(i) - Failed to slope excavations at an angle not
  steeper than one and one-half horizontal to one vertical . . .
	Citation 4 (Willful) 
	1. SCCR 71, 1-1926.651(k)(1) - Failure to make daily
  inspections of excavations . . . by a competent person for evidence of a
  situation that could result in possible cave-ins, . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A
  competent person is defined by the Act as:  

	[O]ne who is capable of identifying existing and predictable
  hazards in the surroundings, or working conditions which are unsanitary,
  hazardous, or dangerous to employees, and who has authorization to take prompt
  corrective measures to eliminate them.Â  In order to be a competent person for
  the purpose of this standard one must have had special training in, and be
  knowledgeable about soils analysis . . . the use of protective systems, and the
  requirements of this standard.Â  

S.C.
  Code Regs. 71, 1-1926.650(b) (1991).  
Burriss
  filed a notice of protest and a hearing was held before a single Review Board
  member.Â  At the hearing, Burriss did not contest the four serious violations
  under Citation 3.Â  The only issue before the Review Board member was the classification
  of a willful violation under Citation 4.Â   
At the
  hearing, Tommy Burriss testified he had been to the Blythewood site a week
  prior to the excavation of the trench.Â  He stated it was his understanding the trench
  was to be just over three feet deep. Â He further testified when he finally saw
  the trench on the day of the cave-in he was â€œextremely shocked to see that
  ditch that deep.â€ Â He said â€œ[i]t was horrifyingâ€ and â€œdangerous.â€ Â He stated
  that had he been at the site he â€œwould have told people to get out of [the]
  ditch . . . [t]hereâ€™s just no way [he] would have exposed anybody to that.â€Â 
 
When
  asked whether, at the time of the cave-in, he was aware of the Actâ€™s trenching
  regulations requiring a competent person to perform daily inspections, Tommy Burriss stated he was not aware of the regulations, nor did he have a copy of
  the OSHA standards, general standards, or construction standards.Â  Yet, Tommy
  Burriss was questioned about an August 2000 citation issued at a Burrissâ€™ worksite
  at Stiversâ€™ Jeep. Â Burriss had both erected scaffolding and dug a trench at the
  Stiversâ€™ Jeep worksite.Â  With respect to the scaffolding, the Department cited
  Burriss for failure to install a guardrail along the sides and end of the
  scaffolding platforms, classified the violation as â€œserious,â€ and proposed a
  $300 fine.Â  With respect to the trench, the Department cited Burriss for
  failure to perform daily inspections by a competent person pursuant to Regulation
  71, 1-1926.651(k)(1) of the South Carolina Code.Â  The Department classified the
  violation as â€œother than seriousâ€ and did not impose a fine therefor.Â  Burriss
  protested the citation for the scaffolding violation and eventually entered a
  settlement agreement wherein Burriss agreed to pay a $120 fine and â€œprovide
  refresher training for its employees in fall protection.â€Â  But, because no
  penalty was proposed for the citation for the trench violation, Burriss did not
  protest the trench violation.Â   
Tommy Burriss admitted he read the Stiversâ€™ Jeep citation for lack of a competent
  person.Â  Yet, at the time of the Blythewood site accident, Tommy Burriss
  testified he maintained the belief his site superintendant, David Marshall was
  â€œa competent person upon my definition.â€Â  He admitted at the hearing, in
  hindsight, â€œnow I know what a competent person definition is by OSHA and my
  competent person definition are two different things.â€
The
  Review Board member upheld the â€œwillfulâ€ classification in Citation 4.Â  Burriss
  filed a petition for review by the entire Review Board.Â  The petition was denied.Â 
  Burriss then appealed the matter to the circuit court. Â The circuit court
  affirmed the Review Boardâ€™s denial of discretionary review as well as the Review
  Board memberâ€™s order upholding the citation and corresponding penalty.Â  This
  appeal follows.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This courtâ€™s review
  of an administrative agencyâ€™s findings of fact is limited.Â  The court â€œshall
  not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the
  evidence on questions of factâ€ when those facts are supported by substantial
  evidence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-380(A)(6) (2005)[5]; Dorman v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 159, 164-65,
  565 S.E.2d 119, 122 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In determining whether the agencyâ€™s
  decision was supported by substantial evidence, this court need only find,
  looking at the entire record on appeal, evidence from which reasonable minds
  could reach the same conclusion that the administrative agency reached.Â  DuRant
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d
  704, 706-07 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The mere possibility of drawing two inconsistent
  conclusions from the evidence does not prevent a finding from being supported
  by substantial evidence.Â  Id. at 420, 604 S.E.2d at 707.Â  Further, the
  burden is on the appellant to prove convincingly that the agencyâ€™s decision is
  unsupported by the evidence.Â  See Waters v. S.C. Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 226, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1996).
A court can reverse
  an agencyâ€™s findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions if they are
  â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence
  on the whole record,â€ or â€œarbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of
  discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  Further, a court may reverse where an agencyâ€™s
  decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Burriss
  asserts the circuit court misapplied the legal standard for a willful violation
  and argues, under an appropriate application of the standard, there is no substantial evidence to sustain
  a citation for a willful violation of the Act.Â  We disagree.
The Act
  itself does not define â€œwillfulâ€ nor has this court had an opportunity to
  interpret its meaning. Â In its decision, the Review Board member defined a
  willful violation as â€œcommitted voluntarily with intentional disregard or demonstrated plain indifference to the Act,â€ citing Occupational Safety
  and Health Law, Mark A. Rothstein, Westâ€™s Employment Law Series, St. Paul,
  Minn. 1998, Â§315.Â  See also Valdak Corp. v. Occupational Safety and
    Health Review Commâ€™n, 73 F.3d 1466, 1468 (8th Cir. 1996) (finding to
  support a classification of â€œwillfulâ€ there must be substantial evidence the
  employer, intentionally disregarded or was plainly indifferent to the
  requirements of the Act); Intercounty Constr. Co. v. Occupational Safety and
    Health Commâ€™n, 522 F.2d 777, 780 (4th Cir. 1975), cert. denied, 423
  U.S. 1072 (1976).Â  When faced with a problem of statutory construction, we
  accord great deference to the interpretation given the statute by the agency
  charged with its administration.Â  See Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs
    in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987) (â€œThe
  construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be
  accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent
  compelling reasons.â€).Â   
In
  the context of occupational safety and health laws, willfulness requires more
  than the constructive knowledge or mere knowledge that would suffice for a
  non-willful violation, but does not require a showing of malicious intent.Â  Intercounty
    Constr. Co., 522 F.2d at 780, cert. denied, 423 U.S. 1072 (1976).Â  â€œAn act may be â€˜willfulâ€™ if the offender shows â€˜indifferenceâ€™ to the rules; he
  need not be consciously aware that the conduct is forbidden at the time he
  performs it, but his state of mind must be such that, if he were informed of
  the rule, he would not care.â€Â  AJP Constr., Inc. v. Sec. of Labor,Â  357
  F.3d 70, 74 (D.C. Cir. 2004)(citation omitted).Â   
Employers
  are presumed to be familiar with standards that affect their business;
  therefore, ignorance or even misunderstanding of the standards does not excuse
  noncompliance.Â  Sec. of Labor v. Hallmark Excavating, Inc., 6 OSHC 1898
  (1978).Â  Similarly, an omission or failure to act is willful, if it is done
  voluntarily and intentionally.Â  Havens Steel Co. v. Occupational Safety and
    Health Commâ€™n, 738 F.2d 397, 401 (10th Cir. 1984).Â  Furthermore, a prior
  warning from OSHA may be a factor in determining if willfulness exists.Â  Valdak,
  73 F.3d at 1469.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â 
Burriss contends
  the circuit courtâ€™s decision contains various misapplications of the willful
  standard and a misinterpretation of the evidence and testimony presented to the
  Review Board member.Â Â   
The Review
  Board member found sufficient evidence to sustain a willful violation of the
  Act as follows:  

	The
  preponderance of evidence shows that [Burriss] demonstrated plain indifference
  to the Act in many ways . . . If not intentional disregard, [Burrissâ€™] clear
  indifference to the Act is very apparent by the uncontested absence of
  knowledge of safety and health standards applicable or potentially applicable
  to a rapidly growing commercial electrical contracting business, lack of
  possession of copies of the OSHA standards for general industry or
  construction, lack of [Burriss]-provided training of employees and supervisors
  for all potential hazards of the job, reliance on general
  contractors to provide adequate safety training for oneâ€™s employees, lack of
  attention to the warning represented by a previous citation related to a
  specific trenching safety practice that would have helped eliminate other
  violations, and lack of attention to the practices of other nearby contractors
  at the same job site as to trenching safety.Â  

The
  circuit court likewise relied on similar evidence to uphold the finding of
  willfulness.Â  The court stated the fact â€œ[Burriss] made no effort to acquaint
  anyone, including itself, with the occupational safety and health regulations .
  . . [and] did not even possess a copy of the occupational safety and health
  standardsâ€ evidenced Burrissâ€™ plain indifference to general safety
  considerations.  
We
  find there is evidence of a willful violation from the complete absence of
  knowledge by Burriss of the safety and health standards applicable to its
  business at the time of the cave-in.Â  Burris does not dispute he was previously
  cited for various violations of OSHA standards, one of which was similar to the
  citation at issue herein.Â  As indicated, the circuit court found Burris made no
  effort whatsoever to acquaint himself or anyone else with the applicable standards.
An
  intentional disregard or plain indifference to the required standards suffices
  to demonstrate a willful act.Â  One cannot be aware of the existence of
  regulatory standards, have the means to review and learn them, consciously fail
  to do so and then use lack of knowledge as an excuse.Â  To willfully turn oneâ€™s
  head to knowledge and to understanding the requirements of the law after being
  exposed to a similar citation in the past is tantamount to a conscious act, a
  conscious disregard, which would meet the definition of a willful act.Â  Oneâ€™s
  act of avoiding knowledge or completely disregarding it might also be labeled
  as an intentional and voluntary act. Arguably, some form of indifference, in
  and of itself, without more, may not rise to the level of a willful act.
  However, we need not reach that question since the type of indifference herein
  indeed rises to the level of a willful act or conscious disregard of the existence
  of the standards and is much more than just a misunderstanding or a mere
  negligent or careless act.Â  The policy of the law does not provide a shield to
  one who is consciously aware of a regulatory scheme but intentionally
  disregards or chooses to disavail himself of, or avoid, such knowledge or
  requirements.Â  To do otherwise would defeat the intent and goals of the
  regulatory scheme.
Because
  we find this evidence alone sufficient to support a finding of willfulness, we
  need not determine whether the circuit court erred in its application of the
  willful standard or interpretation of the other evidence as suggested by
  Burriss.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF
  and PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] The text of Section 71, 1-1926.651(k)(1) does not
  appear in the South Carolina Code of Regulations.Â  Instead, subarticle 7
  indicates South Carolina law incorporates the federal Occupational Safety and Health
  Act (OSHA) Regulation 29 C.F.R. Â§1926, with a few exceptions.Â  S.C. Code Regs.
  ch.71, subart. 7 (1991).Â  This is the case with many other South Carolina
  Occupational Safety and Health Regulations.Â  See e.g. S.C. Code
  Regs. ch.71, subarts. 6 & 8 (1991).Â   
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] Burris is a family-owned business with Tommy Burriss
  as project manager and his wife, Christine Burriss, as president. Â Â Â 
[4] In
  addition to citing an employer for a violation, the Department can classify the
  violation as: repeat, serious, or willful. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§41-15-320 (Supp.
  2006).Â  Additional penalties are applied
  if any of these heightened classifications are used.Â  Id.Â   
[5] This court notes Act 387, effective July 1,
  2006, has since modified S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§1-23-380 and certain appellate procedures.Â  However, we review Burrissâ€™ claim pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-380(A)(6) (2005) rather than S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007) due to the fact the case arose under the
  prior appellate procedure.Â  Regardless, as applied to this case, the only
  difference between the two statutes is the numbering of the statutory
  provisions.

title: Lee v. Regal
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Robert E. Lee, Respondent,
				v.
				Regal, Inc.,
      d/b/a Diamonds, and Edward Bell, a/k/a Eddie Bell, Defendants,
				of whom Regal,
      Inc., d/b/a Diamonds, is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master In Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-071
Submitted January 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January
  24, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John F. Martin, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Kerry W. Koon and Philip A. Middleton, both of Charleston, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this tort action, Regal, Inc. (Regal) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order finding
  Regal liable for the assault of
  Robert E. Lee by one of Regalâ€™s employees.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
I.  Background
At the time of the incident on March 28, 1996, Robert E. Lee (Lee)
  was married to Jennifer Diane Lee (Jennifer) and had two small children.Â  Lee was
  a carpenter who generally depended on government contracts for work. Â However,
  approximately six months prior to March 28, Lee faced difficulty with his
  primary employer and was no longer receiving work from the government.Â  Due to
  the strain on the familyâ€™s budget resulting from Leeâ€™s inability to find work,
  Jennifer decided to seek employment in the adult entertainment industry.Â  Subsequently,
  Jennifer became employed by Diamonds Gentlemenâ€™s Club (Diamonds), located on Pittsburg Avenue in Charleston, South Carolina.[2]Â Â  

II.  The Incident
Diamonds has standard procedures regarding exotic dancers and
  requires each dancer disrobe by the â€œthird song of a three song set when the
  exotic dancer is performing.â€Â  However, Jennifer refused to follow the
  procedure and was suspended from her employment on March 27, 1996.Â  Despite her
  suspension, Lee took Jennifer to work the next evening.Â  When Jennifer entered
  the club, the assistant manager told her she had been fired and must leave the
  premises.Â  Consequently, Jennifer â€œwaited for [Lee] to return to
  their home in Summerville and called him and told him what happened and asked
  him to come pick her up.â€Â  Upon hearing of Jenniferâ€™s dismissal, Lee called
  Diamonds and asked to speak with Eddie Bell, the club manager.Â  Following a
  heated discourse over the phone, Lee drove to Diamonds to pick up Jennifer.
After
  arriving at Diamonds, Lee told the assistant managers waiting at the entrance
  he wished to speak to Bell.Â  In response, â€œ[Lee] was told on several occasions [Bell] would not speak with him, and further, it was inferred it would be unsafe for him to
  talk to [Bell].â€Â  Nevertheless, Lee persisted in his attempt to speak with Bell for several minutes but finally turned and walked Jennifer back to their vehicle.Â 
  While Lee and Jennifer were returning to the vehicle, Bell â€œsuddenly emerged
  from the club and viciously assaulted [Lee].â€ Â 
III.  Trial
  Proceedings
Subsequently, Lee brought an action against Regal and Bell, asserting Bell assaulted him in the course of Regalâ€™s business.Â  At trial,
  Regal maintained Bell was acting outside the scope of his employment, and thus,
  Regal was not liable for the assault.Â  Despite Regalâ€™s contention, the trial
  court ruled in favor of Lee finding (1) Bell was an employee of Regal; (2) Bell committed an assault upon Lee; (3) Bell was performing the business of Regal at the
  time of the assault; and (4) Leeâ€™s injuries â€œwere a direct and proximate result
  of the assault of [Regalâ€™s] employee, [Bell].â€Â  The trial court further
  concluded Regal was liable for Bellâ€™s assault under the doctrine of respondeat superior and awarded Lee the sum of $116,000 damages, both actual and
  punitive, plus costs.[3] Â This appeal followed. 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial court is required
  to view the evidence and the inferences reasonably drawn therefrom in the light
  most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  This court must follow the same standard.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 299, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Accordingly, this court will only reverse
  the trial court when no evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Steinke
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520
  S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Directed Verdict Upon
  Release of Co-Defendant
Regal
  argues the trial court erred by failing to grant a directed verdict upon the
  dismissal of Regalâ€™s co-defendant, Bell.Â  We disagree.
Regal was sued under a respondeat superior theory by
  which an employer is made liable for the acts of an employee acting within the
  scope of his employment.Â  To maintain this action, it is not necessary to sue
  both the employer and employee.Â  However, â€œwhen a principal and servant are
  sued together, a principal is not responsible for punitive damages under respondeat superior when the agent was exonerated from liability.â€Â  Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., 358 S.C. 298, 319, 594 S.E.2d 867, 878
  (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In the case sub judice, Bell was dismissed as a
  party to the case, but was not exonerated from liability.[4]Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court
  did not err in refusing to grant Regal a directed verdict upon Bellâ€™s dismissal from the case.
II.  Course and Scope of Bellâ€™s Employment
Regal
  also argues the trial court erred in failing to grant a directed verdict in
  favor of Regal because Bell was not acting within the course and scope of his employment
  at the time of the incident.Â  We disagree.
As
  indicated, under the doctrine of respondeat superior, an employer
  is liable for the acts of an employee acting within the scope of employment.Â  S.C. Ins. Co. v. James
    C. Greene & Co., 290 S.C. 171, 179, 348 S.E.2d 617, 621 (Ct. App.
  1986).Â  In Jamison v. Howard, 271 S.C. 385, 388-91,
  247 S.E.2d 450, 451-53 (1978), appeal after remand, 275 S.C. 344, 271
  S.E.2d 116 (1980), a majority of the supreme court rejected the Restatement
  approach in favor of the test applied in Jones v. Elbert, 211 S.C. 553,
  34 S.E.2d 796 (1945).Â  Under the Jones test, finding the particular act
  creating liability was within the servantâ€™s authority is unnecessary. Nor must the
  act have been made for the purpose of performing the work the servant was
  employed to do.Â  According to the Jones court, â€œ[i]f the servant is
  doing some act in furtherance of the masterâ€™s business, he will be regarded as
  acting within the scope of his employment, although he may exceed his
  authority.â€Â  211 S.C. at 558, 34 S.E.2d at 798-99 (quoting Cantrell v. Claussenâ€™s
    Bakery, 172 S.C. 490, 174 S.E. 438, 440 (1934).Â  However, â€œif the servant
  acts for some independent purpose of his own, wholly disconnected with the
  furtherance of his masterâ€™s business, his conduct falls outside the scope of
  his employment.â€Â  Crittenden v. Thompson-Walker Co., 288 S.C. 112, 115-16, 341 S.E.2d
  385, 387 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Finally, â€œif there is
  doubt as to whether the servant in injuring a third party was acting within the
  scope of his employment, the doubt will be resolved against the master, at
  least to the extent of requiring the question to be submitted to the jury for
  determination.â€ Id.
In Armstrong
  v. Food Lion, Inc., 371 S.C. 271, 639 S.E.2d 50 (2006), the court
  reiterated these principles and found that the employees therein were not
  acting within the scope of employment or in furtherance of the storeâ€™s business
  when they attacked some customers.Â  The Supreme Court distinguished Crittenden
  and Jones and noted that in those cases, the assaults occurred not only in
  connection with the employerâ€™s business but also with the purpose in some way to
  further the employerâ€™s business.Â  Id.
Similarly, in the present case, conflicting evidence in the record
  supports the trial courtâ€™s finding Bell acted not only in connection with the
  employerâ€™s business but also in furtherance thereof when he assaulted Lee.Â 
  According to the record, the assault occurred near Diamondsâ€™ premises during
  normal working hours.Â  Moreover, Bell testified he came to the club
  to prepare for a charity function and to consult with the assistant manager regarding
  the dismissal of Jennifer.Â  Both of these activities were incidental to Bellâ€™s general duty as club manager to further the business of Diamonds.Â  Thus, Bell was working in connection with Regalâ€™s business and within
  the scope of his employment at the time of the assault.Â  Furthermore, Bellâ€™s relationship to Lee arose solely from his position as Diamondsâ€™ manager.Â  Indeed, the
  purpose of the assault was to convince Lee and his wife to leave Diamondsâ€™
  premises. Â Furthermore, Bell testified, â€œit was the policy of Diamonds not to
  call the police but rather handle disruptions on their own.â€Â  Consequently,
  although Regal maintains the assault was outside the scope of Bellâ€™s authority,
  the trial court was presented with conflicting inferences from which it may reasonably
  conclude the assault was an act in furtherance of Regalâ€™s business.Â  Accordingly, since there is a factual
    basis to support the courtâ€™s decision, we may not substitute our judgment for
    that of the trial court and therefore affirm the courtâ€™s determination holding
    Regal liable for Bellâ€™s assault on Lee.
III.  Comparative Fault, Doctrine
  of Mutual Combat, and Negligent Employment
Regal
  maintains the trial court erred by failing to apportion fault under the doctrine
  of comparative fault, by failing to apply the doctrine of mutual combat to bar
  Leeâ€™s claim, and by finding Regal liable under the theory of negligent
  employment.Â  We find these issues are not preserved for our review.  
In
  order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  See Lucas v. Rawl
    Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004); see also In re Michael H., 360 S.C.
  540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be
  raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal,
  it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  In
  the present case, the record contains no indication the trial court ruled on the
  issues of comparative fault,[5] mutual combat, or
  negligent employment.Â  Moreover, Regal
  did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion requesting a ruling on any of these
  issues.[6]Â 
  Accordingly, Regalâ€™s claims regarding comparative fault, mutual combat, and
  negligent employment are not preserved for our review.Â   
IV.  Punitive Damages
Regal
  also argues the trial court erred by awarding punitive damages in the amount of
  $50,000.Â  We disagree.  
Punitive damages, also known as exemplary damages, are imposed as
  punishment.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378-79, 529 S.E.2d 528, 533 (2000).Â  Punitive damages are allowed in the interest of society
  in the nature of punishment and as a warning and example to deter the wrongdoer
  and others from committing like offenses in the future.Â  Id.Â  Moreover, punitive damages serve to vindicate a private
  right by requiring the wrongdoer to pay money to the injured party.Â  Id.Â 
  Accordingly, punitive damages serve at least three important purposes: (1)
  punishment of the defendantâ€™s reckless, willful, wanton, or malicious conduct;
  (2) deterrence of similar future conduct by the defendant or others; and (3) compensation for
  the reckless or willful invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s private rights.Â  Id.Â  
 
â€œOn the issue
  of punitive damages, the highest burden of proof known to the civil law is
  applicable.â€ Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., Inc., 358 S.C.
  298, 313, 594 S.E.2d 867, 875 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Section 15-33-135 of the South Carolina Code (2005) provides: â€œIn any civil action where
  punitive damages are claimed, the plaintiff has the burden of proving such
  damages by clear and convincing evidence.â€Â  Thus, punitive damages can only be awarded where the plaintiff
  proves by clear and convincing evidence the defendantâ€™s misconduct was willful,
  wanton, or in reckless disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s rights.Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 220, 479 S.E.2d 35, 45-46 (1996), appeal
    after remand, 331 S.C. 575, 503 S.E.2d 458 (1998).
While there is no formula or standard used as a measure for
  assessing punitive damages, factors relevant to consideration of punitive
  damages include: (1) the character of the
  defendantâ€™s acts; (2) the nature and extent of the harm to plaintiff which
  defendant caused or intended to cause; (3) defendantâ€™s degree of
    culpability; (4) the punishment imposed; (5) duration of the conduct; (6) defendantâ€™s awareness or concealment; (7) the existence of similar past conduct; (8) likelihood the award will deter the defendant or others
    from like conduct; (9)
  whether the award is reasonably related to the harm likely to result from such
  conduct; and (10) defendantâ€™s wealth or
  ability to pay.Â  See Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 111-12, 406
  S.E.2d 350, 354 (1991); see also Welch v. Epstein, 342
  S.C. 279, 306, 536 S.E.2d 408, 422 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œUnder Gamble, the trial court is not required
  to make findings of fact for each factor to uphold a punitive damage award.â€).Â  While the trial court did not make
    specific findings as to each factor and was not required to do so, we note that
    no post-trial motion was ever made asking the court to address these matters.

	In South Carolina, post-trial relief in the form of motions for judgment notwithstanding the
  verdict, new trial, or new trial nisi are available to defendants
  claiming a verdict excessive. See S.C.R.C.P. Rules 50 and 59. Moreover,
  although there is no precise formula for measuring a punitive damage award, if
  the trial judge â€œis convinced that the amount awarded is overliberal, he has
  the authority and corresponding duty to reduce the verdict by order nisi.â€ 
	Hicks v. Herring, 246 S.C. 429, 436, 144 S.E.2d 151, 154 (1965).
  (Emphasis supplied).

Gamble, 305 S.C. at 111, 406 S.E.2d at 354.Â  Here there is nothing in the
  record demonstrating that the judge was given an opportunity to address these
  matters pursuant to the filing of any post-trial motions.
In State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins.
  Co. v. Campbell, 538 U.S. 408, 424-25 (2003), the United States Supreme Court, in discussing punitive damages, stated:

	[W]e have been
  reluctant to identify concrete constitutional limits on the ratio between harm,
  or potential harm, to the plaintiff and the punitive damages award. Â We decline
  again to impose a bright-line ratio which a punitive damages award cannot
  exceed. Â Our jurisprudence and the principles it has now established
  demonstrate, however, that, in practice, few awards exceeding a single-digit
  ratio between punitive and compensatory damages, to a significant degree, will
  satisfy due process.

Campbell further explained: â€œWhile these ratios
  are not binding, they are instructive. They demonstrate what should be obvious:
  Single-digit multipliers are more likely to comport with due process, while
  still achieving the Stateâ€™s goals of deterrence and retribution . . . .â€Â  Id. at 425.
Under
  our jurisprudence, the trial court is vested with considerable discretion in
  assessing the amount of a punitive damage award.Â  Accordingly, the appellate
  courtâ€™s review of the amount of punitive damages is limited to correction of
  legal errors. See Austin, 358 S.C. at 314, 594 S.E.2d at 875. Â Thus, this
  court must affirm the trial courtâ€™s punitive damages award if any evidence
  reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s factual findings.Â  Id.  
Applying this analysis to the present case, we find no
  due process error in the award of punitive damages awarded to Lee.Â  The trial court awarded Lee punitive damages approximately
  0.75 times his actual damages.Â  While Regal contends the punitive damage
  award was based on improper considerations by the trial court, Regal fails to
  analyze the issue of actual damages as compared to punitive damages.Â  Although there is no mathematical test under the due
  process analysis, we note the award does not exceed a
  single-digit ratio between Leeâ€™s punitive and actual damages, consistent with Campbell.Â  Under Welch, Gamble, and Campbell , the punitive damage award to Lee was not excessive or grossly
  disproportionate.Â  Accordingly, we find the punitive damage award to Lee
  comports with due process; thus, the trial court did
  not err in awarding Lee $50,000 in punitive damages.Â   
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we hold there is sufficient evidence of record to support the
  trial courtâ€™s conclusion that Regal was liable for the assault committed by Bell under the doctrine of respondeat superior.Â  We further hold the amount
  of punitive damages awarded to Lee was not excessive or disproportionate.Â 
  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED. 
HUFF
  and PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Regal is the owner and operator of Diamonds.
[3] Specifically, the trial court concluded Lee suffered
  damages as follows: (1) medical expenses: $16,000; (2) pain and suffering:
  $50,000; and (3) punitive damages: $50,000.  
[4] Indeed, Bell pled guilty to
  simple assault prior to trial.Â   
[5] While pled and argued, the final order does not
  address the defense of comparative fault because negligence was not at issue.Â 
  Rather, the primary cause of action was the intentional tort of simple
  assault.Â  Thus, the doctrine of comparative fault does not apply to an
  intentional tort.Â   
[6] As noted by our supreme court, â€œ[e]ven after an order is filed, counsel has an obligation
  to review the order and file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend if
  the order fails to set forth the findings and the reasons for those findings as
  required by Section 17-27-80 of the South Carolina Code and Rule 52(a), SCRCP.â€Â  Pruitt v. State, 310 S.C. 254, 256, 423 S.E.2d 127, 128 (1992).Â  Although
  Regal maintains a Rule 59(e) motion was filed, the record does not include any
  evidence supporting this assertion.Â  See Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 339, 611 S.E.2d
  485, 487-88 (2005) (â€œThe appellant has the burden of
  providing a sufficient record.â€).Â Â

title: SCDSS v. Calvin J.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Tonya H.,
      Calvin J., John Doe, and Calvin D. J. DOB: 7/18/99, Defendants,
				Of Whom Calvin
      J. is the Appellant.[1]
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-072
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January
  24, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William M. Wilson, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				DeborahÂ  Murdock, of Mauldin, for Respondent.
				Robert A. Clark, of Greenville, for the Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  is a termination of parental rights (TPR) action.Â  The family court granted a
  petition filed by the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) to
  terminate the parental rights of Calvin
  J. (Father) to his minor child Calvin D. J. (Child).Â  Father appeals pursuant
  to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987).Â  We affirm.[2]Â   
The family court
  terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights to Child on the grounds that (1) Child has
  lived outside Fatherâ€™s home for a period of at least six months and Father has
  willfully failed to support Child or make a material contribution to Childâ€™s
  care as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2006), (2) Child has
  lived outside Fatherâ€™s home for at least six months and Father has willfully
  failed to visit Child pursuant to id. Â§ 20-7-1572(3), (3) Father has
  failed to remedy the conditions which caused the removal of Child as required
  by id. Â§ 20-7-1572(2), and (4) Child has been in foster care for fifteen
  of the most recent twenty-two months as provided in id. Â§ 20-7-1572(8).Â 
  The family court further found it was in Childâ€™s best interest that TPR be
  granted.
Child
  lived with Father from the time of his birth in 1999 until Father was
  incarcerated in 2004.Â  Father was released, but was thereafter reincarcerated
  on several occasions, causing Child to be taken into foster care.Â  Father also
  had an ongoing substance abuse problem.Â  At the time this case was decided,
  Child had been in foster care for two and a half years and had a family who
  wished to adopt him.Â  Based on all reports, Child was thriving in his new
  environment.Â  Father opposes this action to terminate his parental rights,
  however, arguing he has made efforts to support and visit Child, and he has
  formed a bond with Child.
We have carefully reviewed this record and we are not
  unsympathetic to Father, especially in light of evidence that he formed a bond
  with Child.Â  We do recognize the policy in the South Carolina Code of Laws for
  reunification as stated in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-20(D) (1985),[3] but we also know the countervailing
  best interest of the minor child must always remain paramount.Â  See Depâ€™t
    of Soc. Servs. v. Phillips, 365 S.C.
  572, 576, 618 S.E.2d 922, 923-24 (Ct. App. 2005) (stating in TPR cases,
  the best interest of the child is the paramount and controlling consideration).
After weighing these competing, yet vital, considerations, we are
  firmly persuaded the family court judge made the correct decision to terminate
  Fatherâ€™s parental rights in this unfortunate and difficult case.Â  We concur
  with the family court judgeâ€™s decision based on Fatherâ€™s recidivist tendencies,
  apparently stemming from his inability to deal with his drug addiction. During
  the varying times between his multiple incarcerations, Father demonstrated some
  effort to act as a parent.Â  Conversely, there were times when Father did not
  act as a parent.Â  In fact, there were months where he did not pay any support
  or visit his son.Â  Thus, we conclude termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights is
